vacancy.jobDescription:
We are seeking a full-time 3D Printing Engineer to join the Department of Engineering Science (central Oxford). The post is fixed-term for 2 years.

The Department of Engineering Science is seeking to expand its experimental provision by opening a new 3D printing laboratory. This will be a large facility with machines from entry level to advanced research machines.

You will be responsible for setting up and managing this facility, ensuring that machines are kept up-to-date, supplied and functional, being responsible for Health and Safety and liaising with all academics using the space. In addition, you will be actively involved in the design and provision of undergraduate teaching, and encourage the wider use of 3D printing within the department

You should be educated to degree level in a relevant discipline or have equivalent experience in 3D printing as well as a good knowledge and understanding of 3D printing and relevant programming.
Experience of working with and maintaining 3D printing equipment, CAD-CAM software, and teaching at university level or equivalent is also essential.

Informal enquiries may be addressed to Stephen Payne using the email address below or Bob Scott (bob.scott@eng.ox.ac.uk).
Further information can be found at: www.eng.ox.ac.uk/jobs/home

You will be required to upload a covering letter/supporting statement, including how you meet the selection criteria of the post (describing how past experience and future plans fit with the advertised position), CV and the details of two referees as part of your online application.

Only online applications received before 12.00 midday on Friday 24 August 2018 can be considered. Interviews are likely to take place in week commencing 17 September 2018.

The Department holds an Athena Swan Bronze award, highlighting its commitment to promoting women in Science, Engineering and Technology
vacancy.orgGroupLocationText: Department of Engineering Science, Parks Road, Oxford

vacancy.shortDescription: Academic Clinical Lecturer in General Psychiatry, Gastroenterology or Cardiology
vacancy.jobDescription:
Applications are invited from the listed specialties for one post under the NIHR Integrated Academic Training Pathway. This is a fixed-term, 4-year post which offers excellent opportunities to undertake high quality research within a clinically excellent environment and to undertake clinical work towards gaining a CCT. In addition to the NIHR funded post available, locally funded posts may also be awarded in parallel, subject to funding and assessment against the stated criteria for the role. Applicants should be medically qualified, ST3 and above, have full GMC registration and already hold, or have submitted for Higher Degree (PhD/DPhil/MD). Any successful applicant must be able to take up his/her post no later than 31 March 2019.

The NIHR ACL post will be from the following specialties:

General Psychiatry, based in the Department of Psychiatry, Warneford Hospital, Oxford
Gastroenterology, based in the Nuffield Department of Medicine, Old Road Campus, Oxford
Cardiology, based in the Radcliffe Department of Medicine, John Radcliffe Hospital, Oxford

For an informal discussion, please contact Professor Christopher Pugh using the email address below

The closing date for this post is 12.00 noon on Monday 6 August 2018. Interviews will be held on Tuesday 4 September 2018.

Applications are particularly welcome from women and black and minority ethnic candidates, who are under-represented in academic posts in Oxford.

vacancy.jobDescription:
Applications are invited for an Administration and Facilities Assistant/Receptionist in the Wellcome Centre for Human Genetics.

The role will be split between the Administration team, for whom you will ordinarily work during the mornings, and the Facilities team, for whom you will ordinarily work during the afternoons. For the Administration team you will provide general administration support in the Research Grants and Accounts teams, and for the Facilities team you will be a receptionist and assist with general administration support.

Flexibility is required to support both these teams. You will have a good standard of education, with evidence of numerical ability. You will have a friendly, personable and professional manner, with a commitment to providing outstanding customer service. You will need excellent communication skills and have the initiative to resolve problems. You must also have the ability to prioritise and possess a flexible and adaptable approach to work. You will also have good IT skills with up to date experience of Microsoft Office.

The post is fixed-term until 30 November 2021 in the first instance and is funded by the Department.

Applications for this vacancy are to be made online. You will be required to upload a supporting statement as part of your online application. Please quote reference 136138 on all correspondence.

Only applications received before 12.00, midday on Monday 6 August 2018 can be considered. Interviews will be held on Tuesday 14 August 2018 for candidates who are shortlisted.

vacancy.jobDescription:
We are looking for an enthusiastic Administrative Assistant to provide day-to-day purchasing support to the research groups within the Kennedy Institute of Rheumatology, as well as general support as part of the core Administration team.

You will be responsible for the daily entering and approving of requisitions and creating purchase orders on the University accounts system (Oracle Financials) in accordance with the University Procedures. You will provide friendly and reliable assistance to staff raising requisitions or purchase orders, process expense claims and run ad-hoc reports in order to investigate invoices on hold. You will also assist the Kennedy Institute Receptionist and provide cover as required (training will be given).

You will be educated to A-level standard and have excellent IT skills, with experience of MS Office packages, as well as strong numeracy skills and attention to detail. Excellent communication and interpersonal skills with a flexible and co-operative working approach are essential, as is the ability to organise own work with minimum supervision and also work well as part of a varied team. Willingness to undertake training, experience of working within the University and of Oracle Financials would be an advantage.

This is a full time, permanent position.

Owing to the nature of the research at the Kennedy Institute of Rheumatology, this job will require additional security pre-employment checks (a satisfactory basic Disclosure and Barring Service check).

The closing date for applications is 12.00 noon on Monday 6 August 2018. You will be required to upload a supporting statement as part of your online application.

vacancy.jobDescription:
The Nuffield Department of Population Health (NDPH) contains world-renowned population health research groups and provides an excellent environment for multi-disciplinary research and teaching. The Clinical Trial Service Unit (CTSU) is a major international research institute within the NDPH, and is one of the worlds leading centres for research into chronic diseases, such as cancer and heart disease.

We are looking for a full-time (part-time considered) Analyst/Programmer to support the programming of the IT systems used to conduct large-scale epidemiological studies. You will be involved in the full application life cycle, including liaising with users to ascertain requirements and refine applications, and assisting specification, documentation and testing of applications.

You will have a good degree (in computing or a computer related course) or equivalent experience in software development. You will also need experience in a selection of the following: C++Builder, C/C++, Java, Delphi or other 3GLs.

The position is full-time (part-time considered) and fixed-term for 2 years.

The closing date for applications is 12.00 noon on 8th August 2018.

vacancy.jobDescription:
We are seeking to recruit an enthusiastic individual to undertake an Apprenticeship with the Finance team at the Nuffield Department of Orthopaedics, Rheumatology and Musculoskeletal Sciences, based at the Nuffield Orthopaedic Centre, Oxford. You will be working with a friendly, supportive and highly experienced finance team who provide help and support to resolve finance related queries for both internal staff and external suppliers. You will contribute to the daily organisational tasks, receiving training and support on financial processes and developing an understanding of the Universitys financial procedures.

Becoming an Apprentice at the University of Oxford is an excellent opportunity to gain practical experience and training. For more information visit: www.apprenticeships.ox.ac.uk

You will gain skills and experience both in the workplace, and through completion of the course of study. You will be required to complete a 1 year training programme that will cover all aspects of the role will be delivered through in-house training, as well as day-release or other distance learning methods delivered by Abingdon & Witney College. You will complete a Level 2 Apprenticeship in Finance and Accounting and you will gain an Association of Accounting Technicians Level 2 Foundation Certificate. There may be an opportunity to progress to the Level 3 Advanced Apprenticeship in Finance and accounting.

You should be educated to at least GCSE (or equivalent), including Maths and English at grade C or above, with experience of Microsoft Office applications, including Word and Excel and the ability to quickly learn other software applications. You should also have the ability to communicate clearly and accurately on the telephone, in person and via written media (i.e. email). An interest in an academic/research environment would be desirable.

This is a 1 year fixed-term apprenticeship position.

To apply for this role please use this link: www.findapprenticeship.service.gov.uk/apprenticeship/-306951

The closing date for applications is 12.00 noon on 30 July 2018. The interviews are scheduled to take place on 7 August 2018.

vacancy.jobDescription:
You will work as an Apprentice Finance and Accounting Technician. This is an excellent opportunity for the right candidate to gain first-hand experience of a variety of roles in a busy Finance department and to develop their skills alongside their formal studies for AAT. The role will offer the opportunity to move between teams at set periods and can be tailored to match a candidates area of interest or study after consultation with your line manager.

Becoming an Apprentice at the University of Oxford is an excellent opportunity to gain practical experience and training. For more information visit:
www.apprenticeships.ox.ac.uk

You will be required to complete a 3-year training programme that will cover all aspects of the role and will be delivered through in-house training, as well as day-release or other distance learning methods delivered by Abingdon and Witney College. You will complete a Level 2 & Level 3 Apprenticeship in Finance & Accounting and you will gain an Association of Accounting Technicians Level 2 Certificate and a Level 3 Diploma accounting qualification. There could be an opportunity for the right candidate to complete a Level 4 AAT qualification later in the Apprenticeship.

College attendance and successful completion of these studies is an essential requirement of this Apprenticeship.

You should have, or be expected to obtain a good standard of general education at GCSE level, including English and Maths (Grade C or above). Good communication skills both and demonstrate an enthusiasm and aptitude for the skills taught in the Apprenticeship.

This role will not attract sufficient points to obtain a sponsored Tier 2 visa under the points-based immigration system, however applications are welcome from candidates who dont currently have the right to work in the UK, but who would be eligible to obtain a visa via another route.

Please direct informal enquiries about this post to the Apprenticeship Team at Abingdon & Witney college using the contact details below.

You will need to register for an account with the governments Find an apprenticeship service, if you dont have one already.

If you're looking to start a career in Administration, then this could be the role for you!

A fantastic opportunity has arisen within the University of Oxford Temporary Staffing Service for an Apprentice Recruitment Administrator. This role will offer the opportunity to gain skills that will help you build towards your future career goals whilst working towards a Business Administration qualification.

Working as part of a friendly and supportive team you will be assisting the team with the recruitment and engagement of temporary workers for University departments. This role involves meeting with a wide range of people and working in a busy and fast paced environment. You will be trained and supported in carrying out day-to-day recruitment activities including scheduling candidate registration interviews, advertising temporary vacancies, greeting visitors and dealing with a wide range of queries from potential applicants and existing temporary workers.

You will also support the team with admin tasks such as data input, responding to emails, requesting references, maintaining and updating the database, filing and archiving candidate registration packs, answering telephone calls and greeting visitors.

The role is full time Monday to Friday with one of these days attending college.

This is a varied and interesting role based in central Oxford where you will have access to the wide range of amenities that the beautiful city has to offer.

Becoming an Apprentice at the University of Oxford is an excellent opportunity to gain practical experience and training. For more information visit: www.apprenticeships.ox.ac.uk

You will also study with Abingdon and Witney College to complete a Level 2 or Level 3 Business Administration Apprenticeship and gain the appropriate level of Diploma in Business Administration qualification. Initial appointment will be for 18 months.

vacancy.jobDescription:
The Person
The successful applicant will hold a PhD/DPhil in History of Art and have specialist knowledge of Italian 15th-16th century drawings, together with a general knowledge of Italian art; familiarity with the Ashmoleans drawings collection will be advantageous. You will have some experience of object-centred drawings research, original academic research and museum scholarship, possibly through having held a curatorial internship, and you will be committed to a curatorial career in the field of old master drawings. You will be aware of issues around collections care and conservation, and will have a strong interest in connoisseurship and drawings scholarship. You will have excellent organizational and communication skills, proficiency in the Italian language, and the ability to manage varying demands efficiently. You will have excellent IT skills with the capacity to use the MuseumPlus collections database.

The Role
This is the first of two successive Research Fellowships enabling the development of curatorial skills and expertise in drawings scholarship and connoisseurship, in addition to the academic experience already gained with a doctoral degree. You will carry out research and writing as part of a major project of cataloguing the Ashmoleans Italian drawings collection, working closely with the Keeper of Western Art and consulting with other drawings specialists. Your duties will include activities relating to cataloguing, interpreting and documenting the Italian drawings collections; research travel; digitization; and student and public engagement. Based in the Department of Western Art, you will collaborate on the project with curators, collections staff, conservators and other colleagues across the Museum. The Research Fellows are supported by the Getty Foundation as part of The Paper Project, an initiative focused on prints and drawings curatorship in the 21st century. This is a fixed term post for 18 months.

The Museum
The Ashmolean Museum has been described as unquestionably the finest university museum in the world (The Times, October 29th, 2009). The Museum is a part of the Oxford University Museums Group and houses the Universitys collections of art and archaeology together with objects and works owned by other private individuals and bodies and loaned to it. The collections themselves are of world significance. They range from archaeology to the fine and decorative arts of Europe and Asia and from coins to casts of classical sculpture. These are used for teaching and research purposes both within the University and in the worldwide academic and research communities. Above all, the Ashmolean is a great public Museum, open to all without charge.

How to Apply
All applications must be made online using the Oxford University E-Recruitment system, no later than 12 noon on Monday 6th August 2018. You will be required to upload a CV and a Supporting Statement as part of your application.

Next Steps
Interviews are scheduled to take place at the Ashmolean Museum on Thursday 23rd August 2018 and you must be available on this date. Please note in normal circumstances only interview travel expenses within the UK will be reimbursed. Interviews may be arranged by Skype.
vacancy.orgGroupLocationText: Ashmolean Museum, Beaumont Street, Oxford, OX1 2PH

vacancy.shortDescription: Assistant Keeper - Curator of Classical Greece and the Aegean World
vacancy.jobDescription:
Applications are invited for an Assistant Keeper, Department of Antiquities (Curator of Classical Greece and the Aegean World) Ashmolean Museum. Reporting directly to the Keeper of the Department of Antiquities, the postholder will play a full curatorial role within the Department and Museum and will have specific curatorial responsibilities with regard to the care and development of the Museums internationally-renowned collections of material from Classical Greek and the Aegean World.

Despite having a Bronze Age Aegean collection, which is the largest and most important of its kind outside of Greece, and a Classical Greek collection, there is no permanent, designated expertise at present within the museum on these areas. The successful candidate must be able to unlock the enormous potential of these collections through research, public engagement, and teaching.

You will have a PhD/DPhil, or be close to completion, in a relevant discipline. You will have specialist and curatorial knowledge of the art and archaeology Classical Greece and the Aegean Bronze Age. You will also have a record of publication in this area and the capacity to produce research of international standing. You will have excellent IT, communication, and interpersonal skills, which will be essential in enabling you to share the collections effectively, efficiently and imaginatively with our many audiences.

The Ashmolean Museum has been described as unquestionably the finest university museum in the world (The Times, 29 October 2009). The Museum is a part of the Oxford University Museums Group and houses the Universitys collections of art and archaeology together with objects and works owned by other private individuals and bodies and loaned to it. The collections themselves are of world significance. They range from archaeology to the fine and decorative arts of Europe and Asia and from coins to casts of classical sculpture. These are used for teaching and research purposes both within the University and in the worldwide academic and research communities. Above all, the Ashmolean is a great public Museum, open to all without charge.

To apply for this role, and for further particulars, please click on the link below. You will be expected to upload a CV and a supporting statement as part of your application.

Please note that applications must be made online and submitted before 12.00 noon on Thursday 16 August 2018. Interviews are scheduled for Wednesday 29 August 2018 in Oxford. Please note in normal circumstances only interview travel expenses within the UK will be reimbursed.

We aim to have the successful candidate in post as soon as possible after the beginning of October 2018, in line with necessary pre-employment requirements.

You will be responsible for ensuring that marketing and recruitment activities are aligned with the overall strategy for the MBA and the School, and will be accountable for meeting recruitment targets for the MBA programme.

You will oversee a team of five regional directors, and will be responsible for allocating budget and coordinating their activities. You will be expected to work closely with faculty and administration, and to coordinate efforts across the School, particularly with recruitment in other degree and executive education programmes. You will be expected to participate in recruitment events as needed and to represent Oxford Saïd and its MBA programme to key external stakeholders.

To be considered at shortlisting you will have a proven track record of success in a business development role with the ability to meet and exceed revenue targets, preferably within the business school or commercial training sectors. Previous management experience is highly desired. You will be comfortable developing and managing relationships in person and on the phone on a daily basis and have excellent communications skills with prior experience of writing and presenting proposals. In addition you will have a flexible approach to work with a willingness to travel internationally to attend events and meetings.

All applications are to be completed online. Please submit a CV and supporting statement as part of your application.

vacancy.jobDescription:
The University is seeking to appoint an Associate Professor in Human Geography, to commence from 1 January 2019 or as soon as possible thereafter. The appointment is to a post held jointly by the Department for Continuing Education and the School of Geography and the Environment. The postholder will benefit from a Fellowship at Kellogg College, including rights of Common Table, free access to College and Guest Night dinners and all relevant social facilities, and an academic allowance of approximately £1,000 p.a.

You will have expertise in climate change and sustainable urban development, hold a doctorate relevant to urban studies, be an effective teacher at all levels of university education, and be capable of supervising doctoral research students. You will possess a proven record of research and publication (preferably relating to environmental sustainability and climate change), including research grant activity and academic leadership.

The post holder will:

  • contribute to the development and delivery of the MSc. in Sustainable Urban Development
  • supervise part-time doctoral students in other areas of human geography and, in particular, urban studies;
  • contribute to the development and teaching of short and online courses for particular professional groups and for the wider public;
  • be research active, complementing and extending existing research excellence and producing work of the highest quality for inclusion in the Research Excellence Framework (REF);

The Department for Continuing Education is the leading Continuing Education department in the UK. Committed to public engagement, the Department is multidisciplinary and encourages interdisciplinary teaching and research. The School of Geography and the Environment is internationally recognised for the quality of its teaching, research and wider engagement. In addition to world leading education and research, the School hosts three internationally recognised research centres and leads cross-university initiatives and collaborative networks.

The closing date for applications is 12.00 noon on 1 October 2018. Interviews are expected to take place on 30 October 2018.

vacancy.shortDescription: Associate Professor of Egyptology and Coptic Studies
vacancy.jobDescription:
We are seeking an outstanding scholar to join the Faculty of Oriental Studies as Associate Professor of Egyptology and Coptic Studies from October 2019. This post offers a scholar with a growing national and international reputation an exciting opportunity to become established as a leader in this field, in which the University of Oxford is recognised as a world leader. The postholder will be elected to the Lady Wallis Budge Fellowship in Egyptology (a Non-Tutorial Fellowship) at University College.

The Associate Professor will engage in advanced research using primary sources in the Egyptian language (including Demotic and Coptic) with a focus on Late, Graeco-Roman, or Coptic Period Egypt, and will publish the findings of that research in international journals and academic presses, as well as seeking opportunities for collaborative and externally funded research projects. She/he will give lectures, classes, and tutorial (small group) teaching, co-ordinating (with colleagues) the undergraduate and graduate degree courses in Egyptology and contributing to the teaching of Egyptology for other undergraduate and graduate courses. The Associate Professor will supervise undergraduate and graduate dissertations, and Masters and research students, and may also serve as an examiner for relevant degrees. She/he will develop the subject in Oxford through conferences, workshops and seminars. There will also be a requirement to participate in the administration of the Faculty, and of the College.

The successful candidate will have an outstanding record of publication and research in one or more fields of Late, Graeco-Roman and Coptic Egypt. She/he will have a record of successful undergraduate and graduate teaching, including experience of designing and introducing new courses, and the ability to lecture in an interesting and engaging manner to a mixed audience. She/he will also demonstrate a high degree of expertise in Demotic, Coptic and hieroglyphic texts of the Graeco-Roman period, and the ability to instruct students up to doctoral level in the use primary sources in these. The successful candidate will be able to show ability and readiness to contribute effectively to academic administration; a record of successful collaboration with colleagues in pursuit of common goals in research, teaching and administration; and a readiness to participate in fundraising activity. Candidates must have a doctorate in the field of Egyptology or Coptic Studies, complete by the time of appointment. Expertise in other phases of Egyptian, and/or in another language relevant to teaching and research in these fields, would be an advantage, as would a record in securing external research funding and experience of fieldwork

The closing date for applications is12.00 noon on 31 August 2018.

vacancy.jobDescription:
Applications are invited for an Associate Professorship of Neuroscience based at the Department of Physiology, Anatomy and Genetics, Parks Road, Oxford, to start as soon as possible. The post is in association with a Tutorial Fellowship in Pre-clinical Medicine at St Peters College and the successful candidate will also be appointed as a College Lecturer at Oriel College.

The Associate Professor will join a dynamic and collaborative department and will engage in high level original and independent research in an area complementary to the Departments research strategy in Neuroscience. The main duties of this post will be to secure significant external funding and to conduct and manage research projects, through to publication in scholarly journals, participation in international conferences and seminars, and via other media. They will contribute to the Departments Neuroscience teaching to the pre-clinical students studying for the 1st BM and FHS Medical Sciences, non-medical students studying the FHS course in Biomedical Sciences (Neuroscience), and limited MSc teaching in Neuroscience. The postholder will also contribute to college teaching and tutorials and will be expected to supervise graduate research students.

You should have a higher degree (DPhil/PhD) in a relevant area of research, show evidence of excellence in undergraduate and graduate teaching, supervision and research training, and a strong demonstrable commitment to the organisation and delivery of teaching in both Department and Colleges. You will show evidence of substantial independent research accomplishment and a strong publication record, as well as evidence of a substantial and realisable research plan which will complement the Departments research strategy. You will undertake teaching in the tutorial context and contribute to the pastoral care of students. You should also have the ability and willingness to undertake some administrative duties within the Department and the College.

Combined University and College salary: £46,336 - £62,219 p.a., plus a College Housing Allowance of £8,628 p.a. and other College benefits. An allowance of £2,700 p.a. would be made upon award of the title of Full Professor.

Applications for this vacancy are to be made online. To apply for this role and for further details, including the job description and selection criteria, please click on the link below.

The closing date for applications is 12.00 noon on Friday 28 September 2018. Interviews for shortlisted candidates will be held on 20 November 2018.

Applications are particularly welcome from women, black and minority ethnic candidates who are underrepresented in academic posts in Oxford.

vacancy.shortDescription: Associate Professor of Numerical Analysis in association with Christ Church
vacancy.jobDescription:
The Mathematical Institute proposes to appoint an Associate Professor (or Professor) of Numerical Analysis from 1 January 2019 or as soon as possible thereafter. The successful candidate will be appointed to an Official Studentship (Tutorial Fellowship) at Christ Church, under arrangements described in the job description.

The combined University and College salary scale has a minimum point of £46,336 p.a. In addition the College pays substantial additional benefits, including private medical insurance, college housing allowance of £14,466 p.a. and £2,200 p.a. for research support. An allowance of £2,700 p.a. would be payable upon award of Full Professor title.

The main duties of the post are to carry out, disseminate the results of, obtain funding for, and supervise research at a high international standard in applied mathematics, to teach a range of topics in mathematics via lectures, classes and tutorials, and to perform administrative and pastoral functions associated with teaching and research.

The successful candidate will have a PhD in mathematics or closely related subject and will demonstrate the ability to carry out research at a high international level in Numerical Analysis along with the ability to teach effectively across a range of topics in mathematics. The duties and responsibilities of the post are set out in the job description.

Please direct informal enquiries to the Recruitment Administrator quoting vacancy reference 135491.

vacancy.jobDescription:
Please note, this role is based in Swindon.

The Bodleian Libraries Book Storage Facility Team supports students and academics with access to a unique collection of research material stored in a warehouse facility in Swindon. We are looking for a Book Storage Facility Team Leader who will manage the afternoon and evening operations to provide this service.

This is an exciting opportunity to be involved in the library warehouse service and to develop a team. You will manage the retrievals, refiles, the scan on request service, and accessioning operations by planning the work, tasking team members, ensuring the tasks achieve the key performance indicators, and organising dispatch. You will also act as the contact point for enquiries from the Bodleian Libraries and other University Departments.

You will have experience of working in a warehouse environment and be comfortable working at height and driving a forklift truck (for which training will be provided). You will also have experience of supervising or managing a small team, have the ability to train and motivate others to maintain high performance and be able to demonstrate excellent customer service experience. A proactive attitude and the ability to balance priorities in the context of a high workload is also essential.

This is a full-time permanent post, working 2.00pm  10.00pm Monday to Friday.

This role involves loading and unloading totes of up to 15kg from the book delivery van, occasional driving on university business, driving a forklift and working at heights. It also includes opening and/or closing the Book Storage Facility as required and being part of the Book Storage Facility Emergency Response Team.

Benefits include 38 days leave (including bank holidays and fixed closures), pro-rata for part-time appointments, extensive training and development opportunities, access to travel and childcare schemes, free entry to colleges, discounted access to sporting facilities and a wide range of other staff discounts. For more details please see http://www.admin.ox.ac.uk/personnel/staffinfo/benefits/.

Due to the nature of this post, the successful candidate will be required to undertake a basic DBS check as well as a financial background check. The possession of a criminal record or poor financial background will not necessarily prevent an applicant from obtaining this post, as all cases are judged individually according to the nature of the role and information provided.

You will be required to upload a supporting statement as part of your online application. Your supporting statement should list each of the essential and desirable selection criteria, as listed in the job description, and explain how you meet each one. CVs will not be considered.

Only applications received online by 12.00 midday (BST) on Friday 27 July 2018 can be considered. Interviews are expected to take place during week commencing 13 August 2018.

vacancy.jobDescription:

The Centre for Socio-Legal Studies, Faculty of Law, invites applications from scholars working in any area of socio-legal studies. The Fellowship is intended to provide a career development opportunity for an early-career scholar and will give the successful candidate the opportunity to develop their research portfolio and so strengthen their future position in the academic job market.

The Fellow will undertake research in the field of socio-legal studies, present their findings at conferences and workshops, manage their own academic research and associated administrative activities, develop ideas for generating research income, be a part of the Socio-Legal Studies Centre and expected to contribute to its activities. Applicants must hold, or be close to completing a PhD/DPhil in a field relevant to socio-legal studies (candidates who already hold a doctorate will only be eligible if the doctorate was awarded within two years of the closing date for this position. Exceptions to this requirement will only be made for candidates who can demonstrate that they are still at an early stage in their academic career by reason of having taken a career break (e.g. for maternity leave, parental leave, illness or other personal circumstances); evidence of a clear research plan in socio-legal studies, have the ability to manage their own academic research and associated activities; demonstrate how this post will support career development plans, and willingness to contribute generally to the intellectual life of the CSLS, and the Faculty of Law.

The Fellowship is for a fixed term of one year, to commence as soon as possible.

The postholder will be based at The Centre for Socio-Legal Studies, Manor Road Building.

vacancy.jobDescription:
The Wellcome Centre for Human Genetics, one of the worlds leading research institutes in the field of human genetics, is seeking a new Centre Director to provide the strong and visionary leadership required to sustain its world class scientific output.

Crucial to the success of the Centre is that it has always had a vision for its work that is current, relevant, and ambitious, giving researchers at every career stage the confidence that their work has the potential to transform the field of genetics and its role in medicine.

As Director, you will be responsible for developing and successfully implementing that clear and ambitious strategic vision for the Centre, providing inspirational academic leadership to ensure the Centre achieves the highest possible standards of excellence in all of its activities in line with the strategic aims of Wellcome.

You will manage the research direction of the Centre, maintain an outstanding environment for the conduct of world class scientific research, represent the Centre at national and international levels, and oversee the effective deployment of the Centres resources.

You will have an understanding of the Centres mission, the capacity to develop a clear vision for its future, and the proven ability to develop, plan, and implement the Centres strategic aims. You will have the demonstrable ability to provide strong academic leadership, to enthuse and inspire, to promote excellence in teaching and research, a commitment to public engagement with science, and to create an environment in which these can all flourish and excel.

You will have a demonstrable track record as a leading internationally-recognised researcher in a scientific area that complements or extends the existing strengths that the Centre has in basic science and translational research in the field of human genetics and disease, evidence of a substantial publication record, and a strong record of independently obtaining competitive, external grant research funding.

The position is a fixed-term Directorship for 5 years in the first instance, with possibility of renewal, and is funded by the Nuffield Department of Medicine.

Please quote reference 135408 on all correspondence. You will be required to upload a CV and supporting statement as part of your online application.

Only applications received before 12:00 midday on Monday 30 July 2018 can be considered. Interviews are expected to be held in late September 2018.

vacancy.jobDescription:
The Nuffield Department of Population Health (NDPH) contains world-renowned population health research groups and provides an excellent environment for multi-disciplinary research and teaching. The Clinical Trial Service Unit (CTSU) is a major international research institute within NDPH, and is one of the worlds leading centres for research into chronic diseases, especially cancer and heart disease.

As a Clinical Oncology Research Fellow you will work on existing, and develop new studies, centred around the use of radiotherapy for the treatment of lymphoma with an emphasis on learning more about and balancing the benefits and risks of current and future radiotherapy techniques. You will prepare scientific articles for publication, present findings nationally and internationally and provide clinical expertise to the research team.

To be considered for this role you will be medically qualified, GMC registered with a valid licence to practice and a Member or Fellow, of a relevant Royal College (or equivalent). You will also need a good grounding in clinical oncology (FRCR or equivalent) and excellent communication and organisational skills.

The post is full-time (although part-time considered) and fixed-term for 3 years in the first instance.

vacancy.shortDescription: Clinical Research Fellow in Cardiovascular Imaginig
vacancy.jobDescription:
We are seeking to appoint an ambitious Clinical Research Fellow, who has an interest in advanced Cardiovascular computed tomography (CT) imaging, to drive an exciting research programme focused on the development and validation of new technologies that allow non-invasive detection of coronary inflammation and vulnerable atherosclerotic plaques using machine learning approaches. Both junior fellows starting a DPhil and senior fellows will be considered for this post.

You will work alongside a multidisciplinary team of clinical cardiologists, clinician scientists, radiologists, radiographers and engineers, and will have the opportunity to translate new applications coming from the basic science labs of the group directly into clinical diagnostic tools. You will be expected to interact with the Engineering Department in Oxford and industrial partners and an international network of experts in the field of cardiovascular CT. You will also be expected to coordinate a multicentre clinical study on cardiovascular CT, and take part in the academic activity of the Department (e.g. contributing to scientific meetings and presentations), working collaboratively to help to realise the ambitious research programme that is underway.

You will hold a primary medical degree together with (or be eligible to obtain) GMC registration. You will have proven relevant experience in cardiovascular CT (clinical or translational), evidence of excellent communication and organisational skills and sufficient leadership and personal skills to effectively undertake the role of clinical fellow in a large teaching hospital.

The post is funded by the Oxford Biomedical Research Centre (BRC) and fixed-term until 31 March 2020 with a possible extension until 31 March 2022. You will be based at the John Radcliffe Hospital under the direct supervision of Professor Charalambos Antoniades.

Applications for this vacancy are to be made online; you will be required to upload a supporting statement and a copy of your CV as part of your online application.

For additional information you can contact Professor Charalambos Antoniades (email: charalambos.antoniades@cardiov.ox.ac.uk or tel: 01865 228340).

Only applications received before 12.00 midday on 1 August 2018 can be considered. Interviews are anticipated to take place at the end of August 2018.

vacancy.jobDescription:
The Department of Oncology has an opportunity for a Clinical Research Fellow to join Dr Sarah Blagdens group working on the Early Phase Cancer Trials Unit. You will work alongside staff in the Oxford NIHR Biomedical Research Centre, Oxford University Hospitals and the University of Oxford. This post includes the opportunity to engage in a translational research project under the supervision of a scientist in the Oxford Cancer Research Centre.

Your responsibilities will include inpatient and outpatient care of cancer patients being treated as part of trials performed on the Early Phase Cancer Trials Hub (EPCTU). You will also co-ordinate and execute trial activities for EPCTU, including (but not limited to) study specific investigations, sample collection and handling, data collection, case record folder completion, maintenance of study documentation.

This post also includes the opportunity where appropriate to undertake the MSc in Experimental and Translational Therapeutics at the University of Oxford on a fully funded basis. This consists of five days of intensive face-to-face lectures and tutorials followed by a period for assignment work.

You will have a medical degree and will be a GMC registered Medical Practitioner (or eligible for registration), with relevant and substantial hospital service, including experience of managing cancer patients. You will also have held post-foundation hospital appointments in oncology, surgery or a related discipline. Training at Registrar level and a National Training Number in medical oncology is also an essential requirement.

This is a full-time post, offered for 1 year in the first instance.

vacancy.shortDescription: Computational Biologist/Bioinformatician in Single Cell Genomics
vacancy.jobDescription:
We are seeking a motivated and enthusiastic computational biologist to join the research groups of Professor Adam Mead and Dr Supat Thongjuea. You will be involved with developing new and innovative strategies for the analysis of cutting-edge single cell transcriptomic datasets and will lead a project focused on single-cell analysis of haematopoietic stem and progenitor cells.

The Mead Group is focused on using single-cell approaches to understand how the normal cellular and molecular pathways in haematopoiesis are perturbed in myeloid leukaemias and in pre-leukaemic conditions e.g. Giustacchini et al Nature Medicine, 2017. Dr Thongjueas primary interest is in the development and application of novel computational approaches for the analysis of large-scale single-cell transcriptomes, with a particular focus on normal and malignant haematopoiesis.

You will hold a PhD or MSc in statistics, computational biology or a similar scientific subject, with post-qualification research experience. Experience in the analysis of high dimensional datasets and demonstrable skills/track record in computational biology, bioinformatics or statistics are essential. You will also have experience of working in a UNIX/LINUX environment and demonstrable programming language experience (such as C++, Java or Python) or statistical programming in R.

The position is initially available fixed-term for 18 months, funded by the John Fell Fund and Bloodwise.

Applications for this vacancy are to be made online. You will be required to upload a CV and supporting statement as part of your online application.

vacancy.jobDescription:
The Data Entry Assistant is a pivotal role within the Alumni Office providing essential support to the Alumni Office with day-to-day data management, quality and improvement tasks. This position will work closely with the Insights and Marketing Manager and other Alumni Office team members to help us provide a positive and personalised service for our alumni.

The Alumni Office utilises an advanced constituent relationship management system, known as the Development and Alumni Relations System (DARS), which supports development and alumni relations activity across the collegiate University and provides a common source of data on all alumni, donors and friends of the University. The recording of all types of data to the highest standard of accuracy, including personal information, is essential to the running of Development and Alumni Relations functions, and as such, Data Entry Assistants perform a vital function which underpins all other activities.

This post will focus on updating DARS with new data received online or offline from alumni, donors, students, staff and friends. This will include communication with the wider University community, including alumni.

The duties of the post are set out as they are envisaged at present, but it will be important for the person appointed to be flexible and adaptable and able to contribute to the wider alumni relations function of the collegiate University.

This role is fixed-term for 1 year, but with possibility for renewal.

Only applications received before 12.00 noon on Monday 3 September 2018 can be considered. Interviews currently are anticipated for the week commencing Monday 24 September 2018.
vacancy.orgGroupLocationText: Alumni Office, Wellington Square, Oxford

vacancy.jobDescription:
We are seeking to recruit an enthusiastic and highly organised individual to perform Database Migration work at the Nuffield Department of Orthopaedics, Rheumatology and Musculoskeletal Sciences (NDORMS). This position will play a fundamental role in supporting the departments move towards adopting the sample tracking inventory software, LabVantage, to ensure that regulatory and legal requirements are met. NDORMS is a large and rapidly growing department and we expect the implementation of LabVantage will be one of the largest within the University.

The primary focus of the role will be to provide specialist skills to ensure that the departments extensive Human tissue collection records are rapidly migrated to LabVantage. Responsibilities will include planning, coordinating and implementing data migrations of records from existing tissue sample databases and files to the LabVantage platform. You will use project management approaches to plan and deliver successful migrations in parallel. You will also manage project issues and risk logs, monitor project progress and develop contingency plans.

You must hold a degree in a relevant computer science subject or equivalent qualification/experience, and you will have an understanding of rational database design and implementation, preferably with MSSQL. Excellent communication skills, including the ability to interact confidently and proactively with a broad range of users is essential, as well as experience in developing and delivering training for software platforms. Knowledge of relevant legislation related to human data and sample acquisition, storage and processing is desirable.

This is a full-time, fixed-term position for 12 months.

A lower grade offer may be made (Grade 6: £28,098 - £33,518 p.a.) with commensurate reduction in responsibilities if a suitable candidate cannot be found to fill the Grade 7 position.

Owing to the nature of the research at the Kennedy Institute of Rheumatology, this job will require additional security pre-employment checks (a satisfactory basic Disclosure and Barring Service check).

Applications for this vacancy are to be made online. You will be required to upload a supporting statement as part of your online application.

The closing date for applications is 12.00 noon on Monday 6 August 2018.
vacancy.orgGroupLocationText: Nuffield Department of Orthopaedics, Rheumatology and Musculoskeletal Sciences, Botnar Research Centre and Kennedy Institute of Rheumatology, Oxford

This is an exciting opportunity to play a leading role in managing and developing Degree Conferrals and Matriculation operations at Oxford. You will work alongside a large number of stakeholders, most notably colleges, Vice Chancellors team, Sheldonian staff, and students. You will take on overall responsibility for operations, policy development and event management, and will take the lead in coordinating annual scheduling and communications exercises. This role is unique in that you will also act as Master of Ceremonies for degree and matriculation events, and become the expert on both practical and regulatory matters concerning these two areas.

You will need to demonstrate a flair for developing processes and procedures, but also be a true people person, able to create a rapport with a wide range of staff, students and guests. You must be adept at using complex database and IT systems, and show competency in helping to develop functionality. This role requires attendance at a number of Saturday events each year.

Applications for this vacancy should be made online and you will be required to upload a CV and supporting statement as part of your application.

vacancy.jobDescription:
The Mathematical Institute, University of Oxford, proposes to appoint a Departmental Lecturer in Applied Mathematics. The appointment will be for a fixed period of 3 years.

The successful candidate will engage in advanced study and academic research based in the Oxford Centre for Industrial and Applied Mathematics (OCIAM) and/or the Wolfson Centre for Mathematical Biology (WCMB), lecture and teach graduate students and/or undergraduate students and contribute to the teaching, research and academic administration of the department. In particular, they will help oversee the Research Groups interactions with the two master programmes (Oxtord Master in Mathematical Sciences and Msc in Mathematical Modelling and Scientific Computing). They will also be expected to lead independent research projects.

With a doctorate in mathematics or a related discipline, the successful candidate will be expected to have an excellent publication record in accordance with their career status and evidence of the ability to devise and carry out an independent programme of research. They will also demonstrate an aptitude for teaching and an ability to lecture at an appropriate level and in an engaging and stimulating manner, have sufficient specialist knowledge to carry out high-quality research and supervise research projects, together with experience and competence in administration.

Applicants should read the job description document before writing their application. As part of the online application, the applicant will be required to upload a statement setting out how they meet the selection criteria, a curriculum vitae including a list of publications and details of teaching experience, a statement of research interests, and the names of three referees to provide reference letters. It is the responsibility of the applicant to ask their referees to send their references by the closing date. These letters are a crucial element of the application file and the Department will not contact the referees directly.

Please direct informal enquiries to the Recruitment Administrator, quoting vacancy reference 135880.

Only applications received before 12.00 noon on Monday 24 September 2018 can be considered.
vacancy.orgGroupLocationText: Mathematical Institute, Andrew Wiles Building, Racliffe Observatory Quarter, Woodstock Road, Oxford

vacancy.jobDescription:
The Nuffield Department of Population Health (NDPH) contains world-renowned population health research groups and with over 500 staff, is one of the largest departments in the Medical Sciences Division. The NDPH aim is to reduce premature death and disability from human disease.

Working within an accounts team of six and with line management responsibility for three staff members, you will monitor budgets and expenditure for general ledger accounts, ensure effective procedures are documented and adopted for dealing with all aspects of financial administration, including the checking and processing of all non-pay related financial transactions and oversee the management of the student finance system.

To be considered you will be a graduate or have equivalent work experience, ideally in a financial management/accounting subject. You will need substantial experience in providing financial support, financial transactions and systems and have a good understanding of management accounting and costing procedures. Line management experience is essential and your IT and communication skills will be exceptional.

The position is full-time (part-time hours will be considered) and fixed-term for 2 years.

The closing date for applications is 12.00 noon on 1 August 2018.
vacancy.orgGroupLocationText: NDPH, Old Road Campus, Headington, Oxford

vacancy.jobDescription:
We are seeking to appoint a Departmental Lecturer in International Politics for the Diplomatic Studies Programme, which offers a full-time Master of Studies and PG Diploma in Diplomatic Studies for diplomats and other professionals from all over the world. As well as teaching, supervising and assessing International Politics and teaching research methods, the role provides an opportunity to be fully involved in the delivery of the course and to contribute to the development and promotion of the Programme.

You will have:

  1. A relevant postgraduate qualification (preferably doctorate).
  2. An aptitude for teaching and some experience of teaching and research.
  3. Sufficient depth and breadth of knowledge in the subject to develop course materials and research proposals.
  4. Experience of qualitative and/or quantitative research and relevant analytical techniques.
  5. A publication record and familiarity with the existing literature and research in field of expertise.

Experience of teaching mid-career professionals and of developing and managing academic courses would be an advantage.

This post is full-time and fixed-term for 1 year.

The closing date for applications is 12.00 noon on 3 August 2018.

vacancy.jobDescription:
We are seeking an enthusiastic and suitably qualified academic lecturer to cover teaching in pre-modern Chinese studies, while we recruitment to a senior permanent position. These teaching responsibilities will require approximately 10 hours per week contact time with students during term.

The lecturer will prepare and deliver lectures and teaching in classes and small groups for undergraduates and graduate students. This will include classes in Classical Chinese texts, and in Chinese history and civilization. He/she will set and mark examinations and projects, supervise dissertations, and assist with admissions at both undergraduate and post-graduate levels. The lecturer will co-operate with colleagues over administrative arrangements, and be prepared to support students as required. She/he will also conduct advanced independent scholarly research and otherwise contribute to current research, including by publication and presentation, and by participation in the activities of the Chinese Subject Group and the China Centre.

With a doctorate, by the time the post commences, in an aspect of Chinese studies, you will be able to show both aptitude for and experience of teaching at undergraduate and/or graduate level. You will demonstrate a solid knowledge of the Chinese language, with the ability to teach Classical Chinese; in addition you will be able to teach aspects of the history and civilization of China, and supervise graduate students on topics in this area. You will show a commitment to communicating and publishing research in this field of research. Your excellent communication, interpersonal, and organisational skills will be coupled with a willingness to take on appropriate administrative tasks.

This is a full time post for a fixed period of one year.

Applications must be received by 12 noon on Monday 6 August 2018.
vacancy.orgGroupLocationText: Faculty of Oriental Studies, University of Oxford China Centre, Canterbury Road, Oxford

The Mathematical Institute, University of Oxford, proposes to appoint a Departmental Lecturer in Computational Mathematics. This position is a 1-year fixed-term position funded by the Department as part of the support package for our EPSRC Centre for Doctoral Training (CDT) in Industrially Focused Mathematical Modelling, and is available from 1 September 2018, or as soon as possible thereafter, and by 1 October 2018 at the latest.

The successful candidate will undertake independent research in Computational Mathematics, provide lectures and classes, and contribute to the CDTs management, all as laid out in the further particulars.

With a PhD in mathematics or a related discipline, the successful candidate will be expected to have an excellent publication record in accordance with their career status and evidence of the ability to devise and carry out an independent programme of research. They will also demonstrate an aptitude for teaching and an ability to lecture at an appropriate level and in an engaging and stimulating manner, have sufficient specialist knowledge to carry out high-quality research and supervise research projects, and have experience of, and competence in, administration.

vacancy.jobDescription:
An excellent opportunity has arisen to appoint a full-time Departmental Lecturer in Databases, on a fixed-term contract until 31 May 2021. You will be a full member of the academic team responsible for teaching undergraduates and postgraduates in the Department of Computer Science. You will also be expected to conduct research in the area of Database Systems. You will be expected to participate in lecturing, project supervision, laboratory work, examinations, admissions and syllabus development, as well as participate in the supervision of graduate students, as required.

You should hold a doctoral degree in computer science, and be able to demonstrate an aptitude for teaching and awareness of pedagogic methods, and possess sufficient knowledge to develop course units in a variety of computer science areas. You will have a strong publication record in Database Systems and at the interface of Database Systems and Compilers (i.e. publications in venues such as VLDB, SIGMOD, POPL, ACM TODS, VLDB journal, and JFP), and possess the ability to write research proposals.

Whilst the role is a Grade 8 position, we would be willing to consider candidates with potential but less experience who are seeking a development opportunity, for which an initial appointment would be at Grade 7 (£31,604 - £38,833 p.a.) with the responsibilities adjusted accordingly (for Grade 7, you would be expected to hold a doctoral degree in computer science or be close to completion). This would be discussed with applicants at interview/appointment where appropriate.

The closing date for applications is 12.00 noon on 13 August 2018.

Our staff and students come from all over the world and we proudly promote a friendly and inclusive culture. Diversity is positively encouraged, through diversity groups and champions, for example http://www.cs.ox.ac.uk/aboutus/women-cs-oxford/index.html, as well as a number of caring or family-friendly policies, such as the right to apply for flexible working, carers leave and support for staff returning from periods of extended absence, for example maternity, adoption or shared parental leave.

vacancy.jobDescription:
The Bodleian Libraries sit at the heart of the University of Oxford and its iconic historic buildings house the Universitys busiest reading rooms. We are seeking a Deputy Engineer to work within a small team looking after the first line maintenance of the buildings, ensuring a safe and comfortable working environment for staff, students, academics and researchers from across the world.

You will be undertaking electrical and mechanical based daily reactive maintenance of the site, including liaising with contractors, lamp changing, dealing with minor electrical faults, assisting with maintenance of environmental systems, conducting general routine maintenance tasks and being part of a priority response team.

With experience of routine maintenance tasks, you will be able to carry tools, materials and equipment and be comfortable working at heights and in confined spaces. You will also have the ability to develop good working relationships with clients and staff and be prepared to work flexibly as part of a team. Knowledge of relevant Health and Safety legislation and safe working practices is essential, as well as experience in mechanical and electrical engineering.

This is a full-time, fixed-term post for 2 years in the first instance.

This role includes working at height on ladders and possibly scaffolding, lifting and moving of heavy objects such as tools, machinery components, building materials and various equipment, working in confined spaces and occasionally handling chemical agents, with safety requirements in place.

You will be required to upload a supporting statement as part of your online application. Your supporting statement should list each of the essential and desirable selection criteria, as listed in the job description, and explain how you meet each one. Please note CVs will not be considered.

Only applications received online by 12.00 midday on Friday 10 August 2018 can be considered. Interviews are expected to take place on Thursday 23 August 2018.
vacancy.orgGroupLocationText: Bodleian Libraries, Weston Library, Broad Street, Oxford

Reporting to the Chief Cashier, you will be responsible for overseeing the day-to-day operation of this busy and dynamic cash processing unit, and providing a high quality service to departmental customers.

With specialist banking knowledge and strong IT skills, you will be required to ensure that internal processes and procedures are reviewed and maintained, and you will work with the Chief Cashier to provide payment systems across the University that are fit for purpose and kept up to date in line with developing technology and relating legislation.

You will be highly organised, with the ability to manage complex workloads in order to meet deadlines, and experienced in managing a team in a high volume processing environment.

vacancy.jobDescription:
We are looking for a highly motivated, proactive, organised individual to join the Ashmolean Museum Development team as the Development Officer at an exciting time in the Museums history, as it begins the second phase of its major endowment campaign. You will be a skilled communicator with a strong eye for detail, and a commitment to developing your career in fundraising. You will have the ability to establish and maintain relationships with a broad range of stakeholders. You will be able to: communicate projects in straightforward and engaging ways; plan and execute high-level events; and manage multiple tasks and deadlines.

You will be responsible for stewarding and communicating with existing Ashmolean donors, including organising high-level events, benefactors visits, mailings, and donor reports. Working with the support and guidance of senior colleagues, you will also actively fundraise for the Ashmolean, including writing proposals, developing special appeals, and developing legacy income.

You will be a creative and strategic thinker, and your ability to multi-task will be pivotal to your success. With good analytical and database skills as well as a flair for building the right relationships internally and externally, you will thrive on the challenge of raising new funds from the public to support the museum.

You will need to be comfortable with databases and data analysis, and will have a high level of IT literacy. You will not be daunted by the prospect of speaking and meeting with supporters, managing events and budgets, and acting decisively when the situation requires it.

The role will particularly suit someone who enjoys variety in their day-to-day work and who is equally happy working on projects independently and as part of a team. You will be able to prioritise effectively and work to set deadlines. This role requires you to act on your own initiative and find creative solutions quickly. Experience of marketing/ fundraising and databases are essential.

You will be required to upload a letter of application as part of your online application.

Only applications received before 12.00 noon on Monday 20 August 2018 can be considered. Interviews are currently scheduled to take place on 5 September 2018.

The Faculty of Law seeks to appoint a fixed-term Executive Assistant to the Dean during the maternity leave of the current postholder.

This is an opportunity for an individual willing to play a dynamic role at the core of the Law Facultys administration and they will be responsible for providing high quality and efficient administrative support to the Dean in all areas of her work. The postholder will also provide support and advice for ad hoc committees and working parties; be involved in developing and maintaining the Facultys links with external bodies and institutions, and will manage projects and new initiatives.

Applicants should be educated to degree level or equivalent; have relevant previous experience as an executive assistant or equivalent in a large and complex organisation; highly effective organisational skills, with the foresight and ability to plan and co-ordinate high profile events, including the ability to co-ordinate complex travel arrangements and meeting schedules; excellent skills in office IT systems; a high standard of accuracy and literacy to draft correspondence and papers; the ability to manage a variety of tasks at the same time, cope with unpredictable volumes of work and maintain a high level of attention to detail in all matters. A flexible and resilient approach and experience of working in the field of higher education or in a law-related context is desirable.

This post is a fixed-term maternity cover and would be an excellent secondment opportunity.

Applications for this vacancy are to be made online. You will be required to upload a supporting statement as part of your online application.

vacancy.jobDescription:
We are seeking two full-time Experimental Laboratory Officers in Impact Engineering to join a team of researchers focused on investigation of pressure and strain rate dependent behaviour of engineering for high-performance aerospace applications within the Impact Engineering Team, an integral part of the Solid Mechanics and Materials Engineering Group at the Department of Engineering Science (University of Oxford Begbroke Science Park). The posts are funded by Innovate UK for a fixed-term of 1 year in the first instance.

The project is a collaborative effort with researchers at Rolls-Royce plc in the context of developing a better understanding of engineering lightweight materials subjected to rapidly applied loads. The research aims at exploiting and improve existing approaches for experimental characterisation of deformation and failure of rapidly loaded materials employed in the manufacturing of large civil aviation gas turbine engines. You will be responsible for the execution of experiments, the development of supporting experimental techniques, the writing of progress reports and the production of documented software and experimental procedures.

You should possess: a good first degree in Engineering, Physics, Materials, or a related discipline, or equivalent experience; experience of the mechanical testing of materials or of similar experimental procedures; computer literacy, including the use of standard packages such as Word, Excel, Powerpoint, Matlab, and LabView; ability to work independently and as part of a team; ability to report and present scientific data.

Experience in instrumentation, experimental data logging and knowledge of the main experimental techniques for impact and high strain rate mechanical testing would be an advantage.

Informal enquiries may be addressed to Dr Antonio Pellegrino using the email address below.

You will be required to upload a covering letter/supporting statement, including a brief statement of research interests (describing how past experience and future plans fit with the advertised position), CV and the details of two referees as part of your online application.

Only online applications received before 12.00 midday on 30 July 2018 can be considered.

The Department holds an Athena Swan Bronze award, highlighting its commitment to promoting women in Science, Engineering and Technology.
vacancy.orgGroupLocationText: Begbroke Science Park, Yarnton, Oxford

vacancy.jobDescription:
This is an exciting opportunity for a finance professional to develop their career by joining the University of Oxfords Financial Assurance team.

Financial Assurance is responsible for providing assurance that the Universitys financial processes and controls are properly designed and operating as intended, and for driving compliance across the University. The team is re-developing, and this is an excellent chance to be involved in establishing and implementing a programme of work.

You will working with senior colleagues within the Finance Division and with departmental and divisional colleagues to support the design and implementation of financial processes and controls. You will be involved in establishing a routine of assurance activity to confirm that controls are operating effectively and as intended, playing a key role in undertaking activities to provide assurance evidence.

The Finance Division employs approximately 160 staff, most of whom are based at Hythe Bridge Street, just a short walk into central Oxford.

This post would suit someone who is working towards or has recently achieved a professional qualification in accountancy or internal audit, or with equivalent experience in business processes. You should have a strong understanding of financial controls and an ability to operate in a complex environment and take initiative to develop and implement with new ways of obtaining assurance. You should have proven experience in a relevant role, and excellent communication skills together with the ability to deal sensitively with key issues and gain the confidence of senior University officers and accounting professionals.

vacancy.jobDescription:
The Financial Systems Support Centre is responsible for the management of the universities finance systems, primarily Oracle R12, Sage 200 and the universities Oracle reporting tool EIS express. The support centre is responsible first line support, system development, application administration, project management and training for the universities finance systems. We support over 8000 users across more than 150 departments, working to ensure that the universities finance processes are underpinned by secure, reliable systems.

We are seeking a Financial Junior System Administrator to be part of the Financial Systems Management team. The analyst will primarily be responsible for setup and maintenance of user accounts, departments and standing data within Oracle R12. This will involve the processing high volumes of user requests, interpreting and understanding users requirements. Additionally you will be required to gain in-depth knowledge of Oracle R12 system security and administration processes in order to troubleshoot, fix issues and make recommendations on system security and performance improvements.

As a security analyst you should have good IT literacy and delivering excellent customer service. Ideally you should have experience of Oracle or similar financial systems, a good understanding of the necessity for security and accountability within financial systems and an understanding of financial processes. This is a junior role and full training will be given.

You will need to work on your own initiative and must be capable of liaising with staff at all levels across the University. The role will require occasional flexible working, including weekend or evening work in the rare case of a major incident or system downtime.

Informal enquiries may be addressed to Paul Moorhouse using the email address below.

All applicants must upload a CV and supporting statement and the details of two referees as part of the online application.

THIS VACANCY IS FOR INTERNAL APPLICANTS ONLY AND MAY ALSO BE CONSIDERED AS A SECONDMENT OPPORTUNITY

We are seeking to appoint a Financial Systems Reports Support Officer within the Financial Systems Support Centre (FSSC) as part of the Development team who are responsible for delivering improvements to the Universitys financial systems, including reporting. If you have relevant experience and knowledge of any of the Universitys systems and process we would encourage you to apply.

Your main responsibility will be to work with the business on the delivery of new and updated reports plus ongoing support of users of the EiS reporting solution. You will work in conjunction with the Financials Systems Development Manager, to ensure that the Universitys Change Management Process is followed.

The main part of that process for which you will be responsible is to work with business users and developers, who may be internal or third party, on agreeing the functional requirements for the new and updated reports.

In addition, you will be expected to complete unit testing for these changes as part of the Change Process and to coordinate user testing with the business through to implementation.

For the ongoing support part of the role, you will offer guidance and support to other users across the University on all reporting aspects, including site visits if required.

We are looking for a highly motivated candidate who has knowledge of the financial processes at the University of Oxford. You will be a team player with an excellent eye for detail; organised, and have a flexible outlook. In addition, you should be able to use the Microsoft Office toolset and possess good communication and interpersonal skills.

You will also be required to upload a CV and supporting statement which explains how you meet the selection criteria for the post.

vacancy.jobDescription:
We are looking for a Production Scientist to work on the TWO Study, a Phase IIb trial of regulatory T cells in renal transplantation. This is a unique opportunity to become involved in an exciting research project using cell therapy in renal transplant recipients.

You should note that, whilst the post is funded and employed by the University of Oxford, you will be required to work at the Guys and St Thomas NHS Foundation Trust and Kings College London GMP facility which is situated at Guys Hospital, London.

Your role will be to prioritise and assist in the complete production process of manufacturing of clinical grade cellular therapy products for the TWO Study patients and to act as “champion” for the TWO Study in all aspects. In this key role, you will be responsible for all aspects of the process including, amongst other things, manufacturing of clinical grade cellular therapy products; labelling, documenting and storage of products according to product specification and quality standards; assisting in the appropriate qualification, process validation and regular re-validations required. You will also write SOPs relating to specific GMP facility and manufacturing operations and assist in the development and generation of product specific SOPs and batch specific documentation. You will be expected to play a major role in generating data for reporting and analysis and for applications to the regulatory authorities.

You will have a degree in biomedical sciences and proven work experience in a laboratory/clean room setting, including techniques such as tissue culture, flow cytometry and cell manipulation/processing for clinical use. Experience in Good Manufacturing Practice is essential for this role, as well as the ability to work both independently and collaboratively as part of a wider team. The ideal candidate will possess excellent IT skills, and will be able to confidently communicate their ideas in both verbal and written form.

This full-time post is available immediately and is fixed-term for 18 months.

Applications for this vacancy are to be made online and as part of the application process you are required to upload your CV and a covering letter. Please quote reference NDSA691 on all correspondence.

Only applications received before 12.00 noon on 22 August 2018 can be considered. Interviews will be held 7 September 2018.
