vacancy.jobDescription:
The Department of Paediatrics in association with Kellogg College is seeking to appoint an outstanding clinical academic to the Professorship of Paediatric Neuromuscular Disease; a person with a proven track record in research leadership who can maintain the high standards of the department. An attractive start-up package will be made available to the successful candidate. This post is available as either a clinical or non-clinical position. The successful clinically qualified candidate will be given an honorary consultant contract with the Oxford University Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust.

The Department of Paediatrics is a world leader in child health research and hosts internationally renowned research programmes in gastroenterology, haematology, HIV, immunology, neuroimaging and vaccinology. Our work spans from early proof-of-concept fundamental science all the way up to its application in clinical settings. The University is currently ranked number one in the world in the In the Times Higher Education (THE) World Rankings and has consistently been ranked in the top three since 2013. Oxford also ranked number one in the world for Clinical, Pre-Clinical and Health in the 2018 THE World Rankings.

This is a vibrant department with world-class scientists who attract the best students, and where there are close links to the OUHFT that enable not only the training of clinical academics, but also the translation of discoveries from the bench to the bedside. The Department gained a Silver Athena SWAN award at the last assessment, indicative of the supportive environment here, and we particularly welcome female applicants for this role.

Enquiries or applications can be made, in confidence, to Natalie Derry tel: 07408 851 596 or email: natalied@wittkiefferccentric.com.

For more information and to apply use this link: http://wittkiefferinternational.com/portfolio/professor-of-paediatric-neuromuscular-disease/

vacancy.jobDescription:
We are looking for a Project Coordinator for the African study sites for the Development of Triple Artemisinin Combination Therapies (DeTACT) project, who will be based in the Mahidol-Oxford clinical Research Unit in Thailand. As the Project Coordinator for the African study sites, you will work closely with project staff from partner organisations to enable delivery of high-quality results that are within scope, time, and cost constraints of the project.

You will have previous experience as a project coordinator with significant experience of clinical research in Africa and in all aspects of conducting clinical trials. You will have in depth understanding of ICH-GCP with proven experience in the field of malaria research. Willingness to be based in or travel extensively to Africa is a must. Experience in conducting data analysis independently would be highly desired.

This position is available on a full-time basis, fixed-term until 31 March 2020, but likely to be extended to 31 June 2022.

vacancy.shortDescription: Project Manager for the MDUK Oxford University Neuromuscular Centre
vacancy.jobDescription:
An exciting opportunity has arisen to play a key role in the newly established the MDUK Oxford Neuromuscular Centre. The MDUK Oxford Neuromuscular Centre is a major collaborative initiative between the University of Oxford (Department of Physiology, Anatomy and Genetics, the Nuffield Department of Clinical Neurosciences, and Department of Paediatrics) and Muscular Dystrophy UK. Therefore, significant coordination of activities between the three participating departments, the hospital (Oxford University Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust) and other agencies will be required and the Project Manager will play a central role in this effort.

Working with the Centre Director, you will lead the administration, co-ordination, management and implementation of the Centre's key aims ensuring that all the sponsors financial terms and conditions are fulfilled, monitoring expenditure against award budget and assisting Centre investigators in raising additional research funds through grant applications.

The postholder is required to represent the Centre in communications with funding bodies, charities, collaborators and pharmaceutical companies. It is a demanding role, requiring the ability to independently plan and manage multiple projects, and would suit a self-directed individual with excellent organising and planning skills who enjoys working proactively as part of a team to achieve agreed objectives.

You will be educated to degree level with demonstrable experience in finance and project management. An ability to prioritise tasks and manage a complex workload of your own and that of other project members is important, combined with a flexible approach and ability to address problems and generate solutions, managing shifting priorities and making priority judgements. Excellent interpersonal skills and the ability to build effective working relationships with key stakeholders are crucial. Knowledge of the neuromuscular field would be an advantage.

You will be based in the Le Gros Clarke Building, Department of Physiology, Anatomy and Genetics, Parks Road, Oxford, OX1 3QX.

The position is funded by The MDUK Oxford Neuromuscular Centre fixed-term for two years in the first instance, although a further 3 year extension is expected in the first instance.

The closing date for applications is 12.00 noon on Friday 17 August 2018. Interviews are likely to be held the week beginning Monday 3 September 2018.

vacancy.jobDescription:
The Oxford University Big Data Institute (BDI) is a new interdisciplinary research centre aiming to develop, evaluate and deploy efficient methods for acquiring and analysing biomedical data at scale and for exploiting the opportunities arising from such studies. The Nuffield Department of Population Health (NDPH), a key partner in the BDI, contains world-renowned population health research groups and is an excellent environment for multi-disciplinary teaching and research.

Based in the Digital Phenotyping Group within the BDI, you will create open source infrastructure to underpin national and international collection, feature extraction, analysis, and visualisation of real-time high-frequency data streams from Wearables and Apps. Youll take source data (often protobuf) and using Apache technologies such as Spark, Storm, Kafka, and Druid, connect them to micro-services using frameworks like Dash. Youll also develop scalable pipelines to process a variety of novel data streams, using methods which include Machine Learning, and working on analyses both independently and in collaboration with the rest of the team.

To be considered, you will have a BSc or MSc in computer science, maths, physics, engineering, or an equivalent field, significant experience of software engineering, having built and maintained projects of significant size and the ability to solve complex problems using elegant code. You will also be able to provide technical leadership and have exceptional attention to detail and problem solving skills.

Informal enquiries should be addressed to Dr Chris Hinds (chris.hinds@bdi.ox.ac.uk). The position is full-time (part-time considered) and fixed-term for 2 years.

The closing date for applications is 12.00 noon on 20 August 2018.

The post will be based in the Departments New Radcliffe House building on the Radcliffe Observatory Quarter site, Walton Street.

This is a fixed-term post for 2 years.

The postholders PA duties will include managing diaries, organising meetings, making travel arrangements, preparing and circulating documents, and completing forms.

The Receptionist duties will include granting access to and greeting all visitors to the building, booking meeting rooms, receiving and transferring telephone calls, and receiving and sorting post for the buildings occupants.

To make a success of this role you will need to have excellent administration and interpersonal skills, have a polite and empathic manner along with good IT and organisational skills, and the ability to communicate effectively with a diverse audience. The ability to work as part of a team, as well as independently with a flexible attitude is essential.

A key aspect of this role is supporting practical activities and trial activities within the Oxford Clinical Trials Research Unit (OCTRU). Working alongside the group's academics, senior team and quality assurance team, you will be responsible for managing the administration activities of the senior clinical trial unit team. You will be the main point of contact for the Clinical Trials Unit (CTU) and will also ensure delivery of the programme of training provided by the CTU.

You will have proven experience of planning and scheduling to ensure complex activities are coordinated, and experience of supporting or coordinating projects or activities. You will have high level administrative and organisational skills with good attention to detail. Experience of working in a Clinical Trial Unit would be desirable.

The Faculty of Classics invite applications for a temporary Research Assistant to join an existing research team led by Professor Tim Rood on the Leverhulme funded project Anachronism and Antiquity. Since the project began, Professor Rood and the two Research Assistants have been collaborating on a general book on anachronism. The project members have also been working on monographs on anachronism in more specific areas (Plato, Greek historiography, Hellenistic poetry). There is a project blog at: https://anachronismandantiquity.wordpress.com/.

Reporting to the Principal Investigator, Professor Rood, the appointee will research and write two articles for submission to peer-reviewed journals on topics relating to anachronism. Additional duties are detailed in the further particulars.

The successful candidate will have a relevant first degree and a doctorate, or equivalent research experience, in a relevant discipline; degree-level knowledge of Ancient Greek and Latin and good knowledge of relevant modern languages; the ability to manage their own research and administrative activities; and the ability to work well in a team and collaborate with co-editors and colleagues.

The Health Behaviours Team within the Nuffield Department of Primary Care Health Sciences is seeking to appoint a Research Assistant to support an interdisciplinary programme to reduce consumption of animal sourced foods, funded by the Wellcome Trust. The postholder will provide day-to-day support in the conduct of research studies, including both scientific and administrative assistance. This may include liaising with research participants, routine data analysis, drafting materials for presentations, and preparing agendas and minutes for project meetings.

The successful applicant will possess sufficient specialist knowledge of research methods and applied research to contribute to the development of behavioural interventions to change dietary behaviours. You will demonstrate an ability to manage your own research and administrative activities, to ensure the successful and timely delivery of objectives. You will hold a first degree (2:1 or above) and a Masters degree or above in a related discipline, together with some relevant research experience.

vacancy.jobDescription:
We are seeking a Histology Research Assistant to join an established team providing an Institute-wide histology support service. The Kennedy Institute carries out basic and translational research into chronic inflammatory and degenerative diseases. The major diseases of interest are rheumatoid arthritis, osteoarthritis, inflammatory bowel disease and cancer.

You will be expected to undertake the day to-day collection, preparation and cutting of tissue samples, histological scoring/analysis and presentation of data. You will liaise closely with individual research group leaders and develop protocols and standardise histological techniques. You will also be expected to provide advice and training in histological techniques for other members of the team.

You will hold a BSc/MSc in biomedical sciences or equivalent degree and have proven experience in tissue processing and histological sectioning. You will have excellent communication and interpersonal skills as well as the ability to organise and prioritise work with minimal supervision. You will also be expected to contribute to reports and be willing to undertake any necessary training. IT skills including the use of databases, word-processing and spread-sheets are essential, specialist advanced qualification and / or experience of immunohistochemical techniques would be an advantage.

The position is full-time but part-time flexible working can be considered.

This is a fixed-term appointment until 31 July 2021.

Owing to the nature of the research at the Kennedy Institute of Rheumatology, this job will require additional security pre-employment checks: a satisfactory basic Disclosure and Barring Service check

You will be required to upload a CV and supporting statement as part of your online application. Please also provide details of your preferred working pattern.

The closing date for applications is 12.00 noon on Wednesday 15 August 2018. Interviews are scheduled to take place Wednesday 22 or Thursday 23 August 2018.

vacancy.jobDescription:
We are seeking candidates for a Research Assistant position to join the Structural Genomics Consortium. We aim to promote the discovery of new drugs by investigating genes linked to human disease.

Genetic and sequencing studies are revealing a growing number of genes with clear links to human disease. Yet, in many cases, the role of these genes, the impact of mutations, and the relevance to future therapy is unclear. The SGC aims to decipher the function of genes involved in human disease using structural, biochemical, and chemical approaches. Our central activity is purification, crystallization and structure determination by X-ray crystallography. In parallel, we develop biochemical activity assays to study the function of the proteins, and (in selected cases) drive the development of small-molecule inhibitors to test the suitability of the proteins as drug targets. The SGC is committed to an open access policy, in which all our results are published and all reagents are made available without restrictions. The Genome Integrity group (headed by Dr Opher Gileadi) has focussed on genes involved in DNA repair and its regulation, but also on various other genes (often of unknown function) implicated in human diseases.

The successful candidate will have experience in recombinant protein expression, protein biochemistry, biochemical and cellular assays, or protein crystallisation. You will purify a variety of proteins, pursue crystallisation projects, will test the quality of the proteins and crystals, perform biophysical characterisation (e.g. mass spec, ITC), and perform activity assays. After learning the core techniques, you will be expected to drive the optimisation and development of research methods, and to help in tutoring new students and members of staff in your areas of expertise. The job involves use of sophisticated equipment and extensive electronic documentation.

The closing date for applications is 12.00 noon on Monday 20 August 2018.
vacancy.orgGroupLocationText: Medical Sciences, Nuffield Department of Medicine (NDM), Structural Genomics Consortium, Old Road Campus Research Building, Headington, Oxford

vacancy.jobDescription:
We are seeking to appoint a Research Associate to develop aspects of optical instruments for the detection and characterisation of nanoparticles in fluids. The work will be carried out in the group of Jason Smith, and the project focuses on the development of microfluidic systems for the efficient delivery of nanoparticles to optical microcavities.

Applicants should hold a Masters degree, and have research experience in a subject area relevant to sensing using optical microcavities, and have excellent skills in laboratory optics. You should have significant experience in microcavity sensing technologies, along with the ability to manage your own academic research and associated activities. Previous experience of contributing to publications/presentations is also essential for this role. You will also have excellent communication skills, including the ability to write for publication, present research proposals and results, and represent the research group at meetings. Experience with microfluidics would also be advantageous.

This part-time fixed-term post is funded by the EPSRC for up to 10 months in the first instance, and is based at the Department of Materials, 21 Banbury Road, Oxford.

vacancy.shortDescription: Research Assistant - Oxford Cognitive Approaches to Psychiatry (2 posts)
vacancy.jobDescription:
We wish to appoint two Research Assistants to the Oxford Cognitive Approaches to Psychosis (O-CAP) group based in the Department of Psychiatry at the Warneford Hospital. O-CAP is a clinical psychology research group comprising over 20 researchers. The postholders will work on a number of studies being conducted by the team. The supervisors will be Professor Daniel Freeman and Dr Felicity Waite.

These posts are for a fixed-term (12 months from September/October 2018).

The postholders will contribute to studies across the team, including a clinical trial of psychological therapy for patients with persecutory delusions in the context of psychosis (The Feeling Safe Trial) and a clinical trial of psychological therapy using Virtual Reality. A key role will be recruiting patients to the trial and carrying out assessments. Experience will be gained of NHS Services and a wide range of assessment measures, including structured interviews, questionnaires, and experimental tasks. The posts will provide excellent experience of clinically relevant research and would suit a person interested in going on to either clinical psychology training or further research.

With a psychology degree (2:1 or above), you will have an interest in the psychological understanding and treatment of psychosis. Participants will be seen in clinic settings or at home across a large geographical area comprising three NHS trusts, this means there will be extensive travel which would be facilitated by having valid driving licence, and access to own or other independent means of transport.

You will be required to upload a CV, supporting statement and details of two referees as part of your application.

The closing date is 12.00 midday on 15 August 2018. Interviews will be held on 5 September 2018.
vacancy.orgGroupLocationText: University Department of Psychiatry, Warneford Hospital, Oxford

vacancy.shortDescription: Research Assistant in Chromatin Activity Regulation
vacancy.jobDescription:
Applications are invited for a Research Assistant to work with Dr Denis Ptchelkine in the laboratory of Professor Richard Gibbons (www.imm.ox.ac.uk/research/units-and-centres/mrc-molecular-haematology-unit/research-groups/gibbons-group-atrx-group).

The main theme of research in the group is to understand the role of the chromatin remodelling factor ATRX in health and how it leads to disease when mutated. ATRX modulates the chromatin activity with its partner protein DAXX via insertion of the histone variant H3.3 into repetitive DNA. It plays a key role in maintaining the integrity of chromatin and influences many nuclear processes including the regulation of gene expression, DNA replication and telomere maintenance. In order to gain an insight into molecular mechanism of reactions mediated by this protein complex we have undertaken a structural biology approach that will complement our ongoing cell biology work. The main goal of the project is to solve the structure of ATRX and related complexes by cryo-electron microscopy and crystallography.

You will hold a degree in biochemistry or a closely related field. Experience in general molecular biology techniques, cloning, expression and protein purification systems are essential. You will be highly organised with excellent communications skills and the ability to independently manage your own research activities. Experience in structural biology (crystallography and/or cryo-EM) would be an advantage.

Applications for this vacancy are to be made online. You will be required to upload a CV and supporting statement as part of your online application.

The closing date for this position is 12.00 noon on Monday 30 July 2018.
vacancy.orgGroupLocationText: Radcliffe Department of Medicine, MRC Weatherall Institute of Molecular Medicine, John Radcliffe Hospital, Headington, Oxford

vacancy.shortDescription: Research Assistant/ Postdoctoral Research Assistant in Molecular Biology of Cell Cycle Progression
vacancy.jobDescription:
We are seeking to appoint a (postdoctoral) research assistant to join the Mitotic Progression group headed by Dr Ulrike Gruneberg. The Gruneberg lab studies the regulation of cell cycle progression and chromosome segregation in mammalian cells. The position is part of an interdisciplinary, collaborative BBSRC-funded project - Systems-level characterisation of mammalian cell cycle transitions. The goal of this post is to understand the dynamic characteristics of the metaphase-to-anaphase transition in untransformed human cells by combining state-of-the-art live-cell imaging and biochemical analysis with mathematical modelling.

The successful candidate will analyse the biochemical mechanisms regulating spindle assembly checkpoint function in mammalian tissue culture cells. The work will involve a broad range of cell biological and biochemical methods with a focus on Western blotting and immunofluorescence analysis of synchronised cell populations. Applicants are expected to be highly motivated, organised and reliable and have an excellent background in molecular and cell biology.

Applicants should possess a first class or upper second class degree in biochemistry or biomedical sciences or a PhD in a relevant lab based biological discipline. Previous lab experience in protein biochemistry, molecular biology or mammalian tissue culture is a requirement; experience with immunofluorescence analysis and live cell imaging would be a bonus.

This full-time post is fixed-term for 12 months in the first instance. Research Assistant position at a lower grade (Grade 6: £28,098 - £33,518 p.a.) may be offered with reasonable adjustment in responsibilities if a suitable candidate cannot be found to fill the Grade 7 position.

You will be required to upload a supporting statement and CV as part of your online application.

Only applications received before 12.00 midday on Monday 20 August 2018 can be considered. Interviews will be held shortly thereafter.

vacancy.shortDescription: Research Assistant; Machine Learning in Functional Neuroimaging
vacancy.jobDescription:
Applications are invited for a Research Assistant in Machine Learning in Functional Neuroimaging to work on the Wellcome Trust funded project “Exploring the mechanisms of distributed spontaneous brain activity”. This project uses a combination of MRI, M/EEG / LFP recordings, methods development and biophysical modeling to advance understanding of spontaneous whole-brain activity at faster timescales than previously considered, and provide new insights into the underlying mechanisms. This research will be conducted within the Oxford Centre for Human Brain Activity (OHBA) Analysis Group headed by Mark Woolrich and based at OHBA, as part of the Wellcome centre for Integrative Neuroimaging (WIN), and collaborating with Maarten De Vos at the Institute of Biomedical Engineering (IBME). You will be based at the Department of Psychiatry, Warneford Hospital, Oxford.

The post is for a fixed term (funded for two years).

You will be expected to research new machine learning for describing the nature of large-scale brain networks from neuroimaging data, while contributing to the management of the research program. You will be expected to work independently to produce research of international standard, and also to cooperate with other members of the research group, and collaborators in Oxford and abroad. There may be an opportunity to undertake a PhD, provided you meet the necessary criteria

You will have a BSc degree in a relevant technical area, physics, maths, engineering, neuroscience, or a closely related discipline; and have a demonstrable interest in the relevant machine learning methods or computational neuroscience. Excellent mathematical and programming skills (preferably MATLAB), and experience of working on technical research in technical work environments are essential.
You will be required to upload a covering letter/supporting statement and a CV as part of your application.

The closing date for this post is 12.00 midday 9th August

vacancy.shortDescription: Research Associate - Cell Biology of Neurodegeneration
vacancy.jobDescription:
We are seeking an ambitious and highly motivated postdoctoral scientist to work in a programme of research that aims to investigate the role of ubiquitin signalling and proteostasis in alpha-synuclein pathobiology. The study will involve the use of proteomic approaches, CRISPR-based modulation of targets in iPSC-based models as well as a high throughput imaging to screen for small molecule modifiers in collaboration with the Target Discovery Institute (TDI) and Oxford Drug Discovery Institute (ODDI) and FORMA Therapeutics. As such the post will offer an excellent opportunity for mechanistic research in Parkinsons disease pathogenesis using state-of-the-art models and facilities at the University of Oxford and interactions with Industry.

You will have proven track record of research in cellular and molecular biology as evidenced by peer-reviewed publications, the enthusiasm to lead a project as well as the ability to work collaboratively within a team. You will be supported by a research assistant and are expected to be able to supervise their work.

The successful candidate should hold a PhD or equivalent degree and have proven track record in (a) molecular biology including cloning of constructs and use of lentiviruses (b) cell culture, ideally of iPSC-derived neurons and (c) aptitude for mechanistic studies using proteomic and molecular techniques, (d) understanding of molecular mechanisms of ubiquitin signalling or proteostasis, and (e) the enthusiasm to lead a project as well as the ability to work collaboratively within a team.

Informal enquiries are encouraged and should be addressed to Dr George Tofaris: george.tofaris@ndcn.ox.ac.uk.

The post is full-time for a fixed-term until 7 June 2021 in the first instance and to start as soon as possible.

vacancy.shortDescription: Research Associate in the History of Haut Katanga, DRC
vacancy.jobDescription:
The African Studies Centre in the School of Interdisciplinary Area Studies seeks applications from candidates for a fixed-term postdoctoral position, to work on the ERC-funded project Comparing the Copperbelt: Political Culture and Knowledge Production in Central Africa for 21 months from 1st October 2018. The appointee will work as part of a larger team of postdoctoral researchers reporting to the Principal Investigator, Professor Miles Larmer.

The postdoctoral researcher will address the aims of this research project by conducting research (both fieldwork and archival) on the social history of mining communities in the Haut Katanga region of the Democratic Republic of Congo. They will present their research findings in appropriate forums including international academic conferences and workshops organised within the auspices of the project itself as well as writing up the findings of the research in both single-authored and co-authored publications.

You will have a doctorate in a relevant field, or evidence that a doctorate is imminently expected; excellent knowledge of relevant research languages and the ability to produce single-authored publications that reflect both the subject and methodologies of the project. You will also demonstrate an ability to work as part of a team while conducting autonomous academic research; including developing knowledge of the wider historical context of the Central African Copperbelt and mining history in the mid-to-late twentieth century with only light supervision.

The post is based at the School of Interdisciplinary Area Studies, Bevington Road, Oxford.

You will be required to upload a supporting statement, CV and proposal outlining an individual research project that you would like to undertake as part of the project. This should be no longer than one A4 page.

The closing date for applications is 12.00 noon on 30 August 2018. Interviews will take place on Monday 10 September 2018.

vacancy.jobDescription:
We are seeking a Research Associate to join an international cohort of postdoctoral scholars within the PEAK Urban project, which is a 4-year, international, multidisciplinary Global Challenge Research Fund programme.

You will work on a project focused on the effects of transport infrastructure that are widely considered to be pro-poor (e.g. bus rapid transit, cable cars) on the everyday lives of vulnerable social groups in the city, such as the elderly, the disabled and single women in poor and/or informal neighbourhoods. The project will work with the concept of accessibility and reconceptualise this to reflect local perceptions and experiences of constraints on mobility and everyday practices. The ambition is to develop a knowledge co-production approach to research and modelling in which a small group of citizens will be trained as co-researchers who will play a prominent role in data collection, taking decisions in the modelling process, and interpretation of results.

The main duties are to develop theoretically informed, empirical grounded research on the effects of pro-poor urban transport infrastructure on the everyday lives of people in vulnerable groups in the population of one or more Latin American cities.

The successful candidate must have a PhD or have a PhD submitted (at time of job interview) in transport studies, geography, urban studies, or related fields. You will have in-depth understanding of different theoretical approaches to the study of the accessibility, everyday mobilities, and everyday life in the city. You must have expertise in participatory research in which local community members are involved as co-researchers. A good research and publication record, judged by the candidates career stage is essential.

This position is available from 1 October 2018 or as soon as possible thereafter. The post is fixed-term for 24 months although continuation will be subject to a whole programme performance review by the funders at 1 year.

Applications for this vacancy are to be made online. You will be required to upload a CV and supporting statement as part of your online application. Informal inquiries can be directed towards Dr Tim Schwanen:tim.schwanen@ouce.ox.ac.uk

The closing date for applications is 12.00 noon on 10 August 2018, and interviews are likely to be held in late August 2018.

vacancy.jobDescription:
The Person
You will have a good first degree and a completed doctorate in Lithium batteries or closely related subject, as well as a strong record of journal publication or other output record. We are looking for someone who is able to demonstrate experimental expertise; with the ability to apply relevant analytical skills, techniques and methods in: solid state chemistry; materials chemistry; electrochemistry; surface science; or spectroscopy. You will be able to contribute ideas for new research projects and research income generation, with the ability to solve problems flexibly and think outside of the box. You will have excellent administrative and leadership skills and will be able to help students and staff with their research and academic duties a coordinate complex research projects.

The Project
Working as part of a team of Professor Peter Bruce we are working on various aspects of batteries.

The Department
The Department is one of ten within the Mathematical, Physical and Life Sciences Division of the University of Oxford, and one of worlds leading materials teaching and research institutions. According to the UKs Research Excellence Framework 2014 assessment, 98% of the Departments Overall Research was awarded the 3 (38% - internationally excellent) and the highest 4 (60% - world-leading) rating, and for Research Impact we were the highest performing materials department in the UK with 90% of our submission receiving the 4* rating. National league tables (Guardian, Times Good University Guide) regularly place us as the UKs top materials department.

How to Apply
All applications must be made online. You will be required to upload a CV, publications record and a supporting statement as part of your application.
The closing date for applications is 12.00 noon on 20 August 2018. Interviews are scheduled to take place at the Department of Materials on 25 September 2018 and you must be available on this date, either by Skype or in person. vacancy.jobDescription:
The Humanities Division is recruiting two research facilitators. The first post will support a group of faculties: English; Linguistics, Philology and Phonetics; and Medieval and Modern Languages. The second post will support the Faculty of History. Each post has a separate application process and different deadline. This advertisement is for the post supporting English, Linguistics, Philology and Phonetics, and Medieval and Modern Languages. Please apply separately for the post supporting History.

The Research Facilitator post is challenging, requiring judgement, responsibility, tact, and attention to detail while working in a busy environment with frequent deadlines, spread across the year. Its reward is to be embedded at the heart of one of the worlds finest universities helping colleagues to achieve their research goals.

The Humanities Division has a strong track record of success in obtaining external research grants from major sponsors including: the European Research Council, Research Councils UK, the British Academy, the Leverhulme Trust, the Mellon Foundation, and the Wellcome Trust. Research excellence is at the heart of the Division, and the Research Facilitators play a critical role in supporting Humanities research.

For an informal discussion about the post, in the first instance please contact Dr Andrew Fairweather-Tall, Head of Humanities Research Support (andrew.fairweather-tall@humanities.ox.ac.uk).

Applications must be made online. You will be required to upload your CV and a supporting statement as part of your application. You must indicate in your supporting statement whether you are applying to both posts, or just one, but you must apply for each post separately.

The closing date for applications is 12.00 noon on Wednesday 15 August 2018. Interviews are expected to be held in the week of Tuesday 28 August 2018.

The Humanities Division is recruiting two research facilitators: one post is within the Faculty of History, and one post will support the faculties of English; Linguistics, Philology and Phonetics; and Medieval and Modern Languages.

This advertisement is for the Faculty of History post; please apply separately for the second post.

You will be responsible for managing the application process from initial investigation through to successful award, and working with other members of the Faculty of Historys professional staff over post-award management. You will combine an understanding of the principles of research and the nature of academic culture with proven professional-level administrative abilities.

As the Faculty of Historys first point of contact for all external research funding applications, you will provide one-to-one support for academic colleagues (from postdoctoral researchers to senior academic staff); work with Faculty Officers on appropriate funding strategies and report on current research funding activities; liaise with the Universitys Research Services and external research funding bodies to ensure all appropriate procedures are followed; and work with other facilitators across the Humanities Division and beyond to support interdisciplinary collaborations. As such, you will play a central role in maintaining and enhancing the research culture of the Faculty, as reflected in the rankings in the 2014 REF exercise.

The Research Facilitator post is challenging, requiring judgement, responsibility, tact, and attention to detail while working in a busy environment with frequent deadlines, spread across the year. Its reward is to be embedded at the heart of one of the worlds finest universities helping colleagues to achieve their research goals.

The Faculty of History has a strong track record of success in obtaining external research grants from major sponsors including: the European Research Council, Research Councils UK, the British Academy, the Leverhulme Trust, the Mellon Foundation, and the Wellcome Trust. Research excellence is at the heart of the Faculty, and the Research Facilitator plays a critical role in supporting History research.

For an informal discussion about the post, in the first instance please contact Ms Zoe Townsend, Head of Administration and Finance (administrator@history.ox.ac.uk).

Applications must be made online. You will be required to upload your CV and a supporting statement as part of your application. Please note that this application is for the position within the Faculty of History, should you wish to be considered for the Research Facilitator post supporting the Humanities Division you will need to apply separately.

The closing date for applications is 12.00 noon on Monday 13 August 2018. Interviews will be held on Wednesday 22 August 2018.
vacancy.orgGroupLocationText: Faculty of History, George Street, Oxford

vacancy.jobDescription:
The Department of Education at the University of Oxford wishes to appoint a Research Officer to work with an international research team on enhancing and evaluating the educational context of the MagicKinder App (MKA) produced by Ferrero International (www.magic.kinder/in/all/app). You will be leading a research programme focused on rigorously evaluating the educational content of, and implications of childrens engagement with, the MKA. This programme includes a team of collaborators within the department, two Research Officers including this post, a part-time Project Manager, and two DPhil students.

The main duties of the postholder will be to co-ordinate a review of the Magic Kinder app, focused on how it supports language and literacy learning in the first instance. The 3-year span of this project means that there will be varied tasks that will evolve over time. The project, however, will involve a number of tasks including a content analysis of the app, carrying out research reviews, and leading small-scale intervention studies examining the MKAs influence on different aspects of childrens development.

You will hold (or be expected shortly to obtain) a PhD qualification, together with relevant research experience, and possess sufficient specialist knowledge in the discipline to work within the tight project timeline and requirements. As this is a highly multi-disciplinary project, the successful candidate could have a background in any number of cognate disciplines such as Education, Psychology, Learning Technology and/or Linguistics.

Good interpersonal, IT and organisational skills are essential, as is the ability to liaise with various agencies and research teams, to work independently as well as part of the Kinder-Oxford team.

The post is full-time for a fixed-term until 31 August 2020 in the first instance.

Only applications received before 12.00 midday on Wednesday 8th August 2018 will be considered.

Interviews are expected to take place in the last two weeks of August.

vacancy.jobDescription:
The successful candidate will work in the Experimental Neurology Group headed by Professor Peter Brown. This group explores the network dynamics underlying impairments is movement disorders such as Parkinsons disease, with a special emphasis on the development of novel treatment approaches. Candidates should be hold a degree level qualification in neuroscience or equivalent with experience of electrophysiological recordings and heir analysis in humans.

Your duties will include recording and analysis of electrophysiological signals in patients, working together with other members of the group on the preparation of scientific reports and journal articles and the occasional presentation of your work.

The post is full-time for a fixed-term until 31 August 2020 in the first instance.

vacancy.jobDescription:
The MRC Weatherall Institute of Molecular Medicine fosters research in molecular and cell biology with the aim of improving human health. We currently have an exciting opportunity for a Research Support Officer to join the WIMM Administration team.

Reporting directly to the Deputy Administrator you will be responsible for managing all administrative processes involved in identifying, applying for, securing and setting up research funding. Acting as the main point of contact for staff, key sponsors and collaborating institutions you will be expected to develop a sound working knowledge of the funders who support the work ongoing within the Institute and establishing effective professional working relationships with all these contacts will be essential to your success.

Whilst this role provides a specialist service, you will, as a key member of the Administration team, working closely with Finance and HR colleagues and, as a result, this is an ideal role for individuals keen to develop their career within University Administration.

You will be educated to degree level and possess excellent organisational skills together with the ability to handle multiple projects and conflicting deadlines. You will have excellent analytical skills and a high level of computer literacy with expertise in the use of spreadsheets and databases.

This is a full-time, permanent appointment.

Applications for this vacancy are to be made online. You will be required to upload a CV and supporting statement as part of your online application.

vacancy.shortDescription: Research Technician - Mechanistic Aspects of Chloroplast Development in Plants
vacancy.jobDescription:
We are looking for a full-time Research Technician funded by the BBSRC for 10 months working under the direction of Professor Paul Jarvis on mechanistic aspects of chloroplast development in plants.

Responsibilities/duties include: Undertake research work involving various molecular biology techniques and the genetic and physiological analysis of plants, particularly Arabidopsis thaliana. Provide technical support and assistance in relation to the experimental research activities of postdocs and students. Responsibility for the maintenance and organisation of laboratory stocks, as well as the corresponding databases. Monitor levels of laboratory chemicals and equipment. Prepare and maintain of stock solutions. Oversee the growth and maintenance of plants within controlled environments. Maintain accurate records and recording experimental data, assisting in the interpretation and presentation of results using computers and graphics. Maintain good laboratory practice. Participate in the laboratorys group meetings. Carry out routine biological practices, e.g. sterilisation, autoclaving/washing glassware and apparatus, media preparation, re-stocking, etc.

The postholder should have: Experience of: molecular biology techniques, working in a biological research laboratory, managing laboratory stocks and supplies. Ability to work co-operatively as part of a team and to learn new methods and skills. Experience in accurate data record keeping and analysis, including use of computers and graphics software. Willingness to carry out routine biological practices. Good communication skills. Appropriate higher education qualification in a relevant subject. Experience of plant husbandry. Experience of working with Arabidopsis thaliana or other model organisms.

Informal enquiries should be directed to the Recruitment Administrator.

All applications must be received by 12.00 midday on Friday 17 August 2018.
vacancy.orgGroupLocationText: Department of Plant Sciences, University of Oxford, South Parks Road, Oxford

vacancy.jobDescription:
Applications are invited for a postdoctoral researcher, research software engineer, or equivalent, to work on a project aimed at automating approaches in computational radiation therapy.

The post is available for a fixed-term duration of 6 months. The outcome of this project has promising potential for creating intellectual property and for building a spinout company. This project aims to build a proof-of-principle real-time treatment planning system prototype for X-ray and particle-based radiation therapy.

The successful candidate will play a key role in the software development of a C++ based dose-distribution model and will integrate it with an optimisation framework in distributed systems that we have recently developed. The candidate will also work on training machine learning models, model validation, and on the development of robust and fast optimization methods for treatment planning systems for radiation therapy more generally.

Applicants should possess a degree in physics, computer science, engineering, mathematics, statistics, or a related field and ideally a strong background in computer programming, especially in C++.

Previous experience in the field of machine learning, deep learning, convex or non-convex optimisation, or computational radiation therapy will be an advantage.

Demonstrated ability in other programming language, such as Python and MATLAB, will be an advantage. Experiences in using machine learning or deep learning libraries (e.g. scikit-learn and PyTorch), parallelization tools (e.g. AVX, OpenMP, MPI), and GPU programming are preferable.

Please direct enquiries about the role to Dr Sam Vinko (sam.vinko@physics.ox.ac.uk).

You will be required to upload a brief statement of research interests, CV and details of two referees as part of your online application.

Only applications received before 12.00 midday on 10 August 2018 can be considered.
vacancy.orgGroupLocationText: Department of Physics, Clarendon Laboratory, Oxford

vacancy.jobDescription:
The Ashmolean is the University of Oxfords museum of art and archaeology, founded in 1683. Our world-famous collections range from Egyptian mummies to contemporary art, telling human stories across cultures and across time. The Ashmolean has seen the success of several recent exhibitions, such as Andy Warhol: Works from the Hall Collection and the award-winning Raphael: The Drawings. The commercial departments growing retail team are now looking for two variable hours, permanent Retail Sales Assistants to help support the departments on-going retail objectives.

The Retail Sales Assistant will work as part of a small retail team at the Ashmolean Museum. The role requires the candidate to be sales orientated and customer service focused. The sales assistant should have experience with cash handling. We are looking for flexible team members who will be able to work shifts during weekdays, weekends, and late-night openings.

The ideal candidate will:
 Have previous retail experience - working in a heritage or luxury retail environment would be beneficial.
 You will need excellent communication and IT skills.
 You will need to deliver an exceptional customer experience in a busy fast pace environment.
 Passionate about retail and interested in achieving personal sales targets and supporting others in achieving theirs.
 You will be expected to be of smart appearance and have the ability to work on your own initiative within a small team.
 You will be able to carry out the physical demands of the role, as you may be required to move stock and set up Exhibition shops.

Applications for this vacancy are to be made online.

You will be required to answer the following two questions to form your supporting document:

  1. Why your skills, experience and knowledge demonstrate you are the right candidate for this role?
  2. Which three key attributes will you bring to the role and how do they relate to selling, service or working as part of a team?

The responses to the two questions should be no more than 200 words for each answer and titled supporting document, with your name. Please do not upload certificates or additional supporting information as they will not be considered in the shortlisting for this position.

The closing date for applications is 12.00 midday on Monday 30 July 2018. Shop floor assessments and interviews will be held on Thursday 9 August 2018, you will need to be available on this day. Please note in normal circumstances only interview travel expenses within the UK will be reimbursed.

vacancy.jobDescription:
We have an exciting opportunity for a Sample Manager to join the Nuffield Department of Orthopaedics, Rheumatology and Musculoskeletal Sciences (NDORMS). This position will play a fundamental role in supporting the management of human tissue collections by implementing and providing on-going support of the sample tracking inventory software, LabVantage, to ensure that regulatory and legal requirements are met. NDORMS is a large and rapidly growing department and we expect the implementation of LabVantage will be one of the largest within the University.

As a Sample Manager you will be responsible for developing, implementing and maintaining the LabVantage inventory systems to coordinate the capture and annotation of highquality data pertaining to tissue samples within the Department in close collaboration with the Departments Human Tissue Managers. You will also ensure that processes and procedures are in place such that collection implementations within LabVantage are tested adequately before acceptance. Other duties include providing support for the maintenance of relevant websites and assistance to members of the team involved in updating the content and assisting in the extraction of data to prepare regulatory-mandated reports such as for HTA purposes.

You must hold a degree in biological or computational science, have significant experience of working with Laboratory Information Management Systems (LIMS) and the requirements surrounding appropriate inventory control and reporting. Excellent communication skills, including the ability to interact confidently and proactively with a broad range of users is essential, as is an experience in developing and delivering training for software platforms. Knowledge of relevant legislation related to human data and sample acquisition, storage and processing is desirable.

This is a full-time, fixed-term position for 2 years.

Owing to the nature of the research at the Kennedy Institute of Rheumatology, this job will require additional security pre-employment checks (a satisfactory basic Disclosure and Barring Service check).

Applications for this vacancy are to be made online. You will be required to upload a supporting statement as part of your online application

The closing date for applications is 12.00 noon on Monday 6 August 2018.

vacancy.jobDescription:
IT Services seeks a creative, experienced software developer to join the Web and Mobile Applications team. We work closely with researchers, academics, students and staff to build innovative apps that make interacting with the University more useful, engaging, and enjoyable.

Were building Augmented Reality apps for teaching with the Universitys collections, research apps for things as diverse as coins and manuscripts, and were experimenting with Machine Learning and Social Media APIs.

We develop mainly in Javascript using React and Node.js, and with Cordova, Drupal, SolR and Django. We follow an Agile methodology and a service-oriented, user-centred approach to design.

Your main duties will be to: develop appropriate and effective technical solutions liaise with Business Analysts, Testers and End Users through all stages of development; take a lead role in the design, coding, testing and documentation of developments; provide training, technical advice, and mentorship to colleagues and supervision of less experienced developers where appropriate

You should have: a strong history of exceptional web and mobile development work; eagerness to work with new technologies and creativity in approaching technical challenges; expertise in a range of web and mobile development technologies and languages; ability to work on own initiative and collaborate effectively within a team.

If you are passionate about creating innovative applications and would like to contribute to the educational, research, and administrative work of the University we would like to hear from you.

vacancy.jobDescription:
The Malaria Atlas Project is looking for a Senior Analyst/Programmer with technical experience of Web application development using any object-oriented language. The successful applicant will be joining a small team building a new application suite from the ground up. The application will support global research into malaria and other diseases.

This is a full-stack developer role, providing an opportunity to work with a range of Open Source technologies, with a particular focus on the Angular (TypeScript/JavaScript) and Spring Boot (Java). Other Open Source technologies used include GeoServer, PostgreSQL/PostGIS, GitLab and Docker. You should be enthusiastic about working with these technologies. While experience with some of the technologies mentioned above (particularly JavaScript) would be beneficial, candidates whose experience is in other object-oriented or functional languages (such as Java or Python) will be considered. Aptitude, attitude and flexibility are the most important criteria.

You will be educated to degree level in computing or IT related subject or have equivalent experience. You should have demonstrable experience of application development and relational database design, whether obtained within project, support or academic environments, as well as an understanding of the importance of team coding standards and technical documentation. Experience of directing the work of junior developers is also essential.

This full-time fixed-term post is available in the first instance until August 2020. Further particulars, including details of how to apply, can be obtained from the document below. Applications for this vacancy should be made online and you will be required to upload a detailed CV and a supporting statement listing how you meet each of the essential and desirable selection criteria from the job description. Applicants are encouraged to supply links to example code they have written, for example a Git repository.

vacancy.gradeAndSalaryText: Grade 8: £39,992 - £47,722 with a discretionary range to £52,132 p.a.

vacancy.jobDescription:
The Oxford University Big Data Institute (BDI) is a new interdisciplinary research centre aiming to develop, evaluate and deploy efficient methods for acquiring and analysing biomedical data at scale and for exploiting the opportunities arising from such studies. The Nuffield Department of Population Health (NDPH), a key partner in the BDI, contains world-renowned population health research groups and is an excellent environment for multi-disciplinary teaching and research.

We are looking for an exceptional Data Scientist to lead the analysis of GameChanger a major new study into the use of Apps for detecting longitudinal cognitive change in population-level cohorts. Starting this September, GameChanger is a national citizen science project which will deploy the Mezurio Smartphone App (www.mezur.io) through a publicity campaign led by the UK Alzheimers Society. In addition, the app will be promoted inside several large-scale UK cohorts such as UK BioBank, ALSPAC, Generation Scotland, NIHR BioResource, and others, to provide a highly-phenotyped subset. Based within the BDI, you will be part of the interdisciplinary team which designed and built Mezurio, leading on the selection of methods, taking responsibility for statistical design, exploring new and complex streams of data, working with the Big Data team to scale up analyses, and with software engineers on the design of new modules for the App.

To be considered you will have a PhD involving a substantial data science component and a BSc or MSc in Science, Maths, Engineering or Computing. You will require a strong understanding of statistical methods for analysing longitudinal data, and must be able to demonstrate instances of solving significant scientific problems using data science techniques. You will also have the ability to write academic reports and provide statistical leadership to a research group.

Informal enquiries should be addressed to Dr Chris Hinds (chris.hinds@bdi.ox.ac.uk).

The position is full time (part time considered) and fixed term for two years. The closing date for applications is noon on 9th August 2018.

vacancy.shortDescription: Senior Medical Statistician - Population Biobank Studies
vacancy.jobDescription:
An exciting opportunity has arisen for a highly-motivated and experienced post-doctoral Senior Medical Statistician to join a research group focussing on the aetiology of cardiovascular diseases and diseases of old age using the UK and China Kadoorie biobank studies with genetic data and linkage to electronic health data. The very large-scale data that are emerging provide the opportunity for many exciting and extensive investigations requiring well-structured data manipulation and statistical programming to yield their full potential. We are seeking to recruit a Senior Medical Statistician with a sound understanding of a range of statistical techniques and excellent programming skills. The post will involve researching and implementing statistical analyses, planning data synthesis, interpreting the implications for population health and providing technical training and leadership to students and early career team members.

You will have a good higher degree (PhD or MSc and considerable additional relevant experience) in statistics, mathematics (or closely related subject), a demonstrated record in statistical programming and analysis (for example in SAS, R) and be competent to develop your skills further and share them.

The Nuffield Department of Population Health (NDPH) contains world-renowned population health research groups. This post, based in the Big Data Institute, provides an excellent opportunity for training and development of expertise in medical statistics and statistical programming within a leading multi-disciplinary academic unit with an unrivalled reputation for promoting the use of big data to reliably identify findings important to population health.

The post is full-time (part-time considered) and is fixed-term for 3 years in the first instance.

The closing date for applications is 12.00 noon on 8 August 2018.

vacancy.jobDescription:
We are seeking an ambitious and highly motivated Senior Postdoctoral Scientist to be based at the Human Immunology Unit (HIU), Weatherall Institute of Molecular Medicine, working for Professors Simon Davis and Richard Cornall. The individual will be required to take responsibility for running a programme of research comprising an analysis of the immunological effects of antibodies that bind to a set of immune checkpoint receptors, funded by the UK Medical Research Council. The antibodies act principally as either blockers or agonists, and will be studied alone and in combination, both in vitro and in in vivo transgenic models of autoimmunity and cancer. The goal is to determine the effects of the antibodies on normal immune responses and to explore their therapeutic activity and potential.
The postholder will provide guidance to less experienced members of the research group, including post-doctoral scientists, research assistants, technicians, and PhD and project students.

The postholder will be someone with considerable experience in cellular immunology obtained at graduate level or as a postdoctoral scientist. The appointment will be made at up to a senior postdoctoral level because we want to appoint someone able to exercise considerable responsibility and scientific judgement. You will hold a relevant PhD/DPhil with post qualification research experience. You will have a strong publication record and familiarity with existing literature and research in the field and possess sufficient specialist knowledge to develop research projects and methodologies.

This post is full-time and is fixed-term for 36 months.

Applications for this vacancy are to be made online. You will be required to upload a supporting statement and CV as part of your online application.

Only applications received before 12.00 midday on 20 August 2018 will be considered.

vacancy.jobDescription:
THIS POST MAY ALSO BE OFFERED AS A SECONDMENT OPPORTUNITY

We invite applications for a Senior Research Funding Specialist position in this friendly, busy and supportive team based in the science area of central Oxford. This is an exciting opportunity for someone to utilise their experience of working in a customer focused environment and to continue their development across a range of research support activity.

You will be part of a team specialising in research grant support, working with colleagues in academic departments to advise on grant application preparation, review and approve applications, manage grant offers, liaise with external funders and provide advice to members of the University about external research funding opportunities. In addition, you will play an active role in University-wide and Research Services improvement projects, and contribute to the training of the Research Grants Administrator. You will be an effective communicator, building positive relationships with colleagues and customers, and have the ability to advise and communicate complex ideas both in written documentations and through the delivery of workshops. You will be fully at ease with using databases, spreadsheets and other electronic systems in order to manage your workload.

The position is available on a fixed-term basis until 30 June 2019 and could be undertaken as a secondment. Informal enquiries about any aspect of this position may be made to: zoe.lee@admin.ox.ac.uk. Further particulars, including details of how to apply, can be obtained from the document below.

Please upload a CV and 1-2 page supporting statement as part of your online application.

Please apply no later than 12.00 noon on Wednesday 8 August 2018. Applications received after this date will not be considered. Interviews are expected to be held during the week commencing 20 August 2018.

vacancy.shortDescription: Senior Researcher and Ethics Advisor in the Ethics of Global Challenges Research
vacancy.jobDescription:
Based within the Nuffield Department of Population Health, The Ethox Centre is an internationally recognised multidisciplinary bioethics research centre and is a vibrant and intellectually exciting place to work. The post will also be linked with the Wellcome Centre for Ethics and Humanities.

As a Senior Researcher and Ethics Advisor, you will take responsibility for the development and leadership of a programme of ethics advice to and support for researchers from across the University of Oxford working in global challenges research, and a complementary programme of global ethics research. Drawing on your collaborations with global challenges researchers across the University, you will lead the new research ethics consultation programme and provide support and practical solutions. You will also develop a programme of ethics research, ideas for income generation and regularly publish research papers and present at conferences and seminars.

You will have a relevant PhD/DPhil with significant post research experience and an established (inter) national reputation and publication record in ethics. You will possess sufficient specialist knowledge in ethics to develop research projects and methodologies in the ethics of global challenges research and to provide ethics advice and support to researchers working in global challenges research.

The post is full-time (part-time considered) and fixed-term for 3 years.

The closing date for applications is 12.00 noon on 27 July 2018.

vacancy.jobDescription:
We have a vacancy for a Senior Researcher to work in connection with the Programme Grant project Mobile Robotics: Enabling a Pervasive Technology of the Future in the area of quantitative verification and synthesis, focusing on ensuring safety and trust for mobile autonomous systems. The post will be under the supervision of Professor Marta Kwiatkowska, head of the Automated Verification Group, in collaboration with Professors. Paul Newman and Ingmar Posner (Oxford Engineering Science Dept.) and Professor Niki Trigoni (Oxford Dept. of Computer Science).

You will be developing novel quantitative verification and synthesis techniques, with application to autonomous driving and personal transport. Areas of interest include: safety verification for deep neural networks and machine learning components, including techniques based on optimisation, constraint solving and Bayesian methods; and verification and synthesis for concurrent stochastic games, including equilibria and partial observability. Preference will be given to candidates that complement existing activities of the Safety, Trust and Integrity theme of the project, as summarised here: http://qav.comlab.ox.ac.uk/projects/epsrc-mobaut/

You should have a PhD in computer science, mathematics or related discipline, post-qualification research experience, an excellent document track record of research projects, knowledge of and demonstrable experience in three of more of: quantitative/probabilistic modelling, quantitative verification, machine learning, data inference, game theory and controller synthesis, and proven experience of software development in relevant areas, such as constraint solving, machine learning, optimisation and equilibria. Experience of embedded systems and/or robotics, and knowledge of cognitive modelling, data inference and statistics are highly desirable.

The closing date for applications is 12.00 noon on Friday 17 August 2018. Interviews are expected to be held on 24 August 2018.

Our staff and students come from all over the world and we proudly promote a friendly and inclusive culture. Diversity is positively encouraged, through diversity groups and champions, for example http://www.cs.ox.ac.uk/aboutus/women-cs-oxford/index.html, as well as a number of family-friendly policies, such as the right to apply for flexible working and support for staff returning from periods of extended absence, for example maternity leave.
vacancy.orgGroupLocationText: Department of Computer Science, Wolfson Building, Parks Road, Oxford.

vacancy.jobDescription:
The Ashmolean is the University of Oxfords museum of art and archaeology, founded in 1683. Our world-famous collections range from Egyptian mummies to contemporary art, telling human stories across cultures and across time. The Ashmolean has seen the success of several recent exhibitions, such as Andy Warhol: Works from the Hall Collection and the award-winning Raphael: The Drawings. The commercial departments retail shops are now looking for two permanent, variable hours Retail Senior Sales Assistants to help support the on-going retail objectives.

The Retail Senior Sales Assistant will work as part of a small retail team and the broad range of duties includes shop sales, displays, and stock maintenance. You will have the additional responsibility of processing refunds/exchanges, cashing up and making customer service decisions in the absence of a manager.

You will be able to work shifts during weekdays and weekends if required and a degree of flexibility is essential when working as part of this small team. We expect to offer additional hours during busy exhibitions, late nights, to cover holiday, sickness and seasonal trading periods.

 You will be sales orientated and customer service focused.
 Have previous retail experience working with comparable products, preferably with luxury goods is essential and be passionate about retail and interested in achieving personal sales targets and supporting others in achieving theirs.
 Youll need to have excellent communication, selling and IT skills.
 Be able to demonstrate good organisation and planning skills and time management.
 You will be expected to be of smart appearance and have the ability to work on your own initiative within a small team.
 You may be required to move stock and set up Exhibition shops (with or without adaptations for this physically demanding duty).

Applications for this vacancy are to be made online. Please do not upload certificates or additional supporting information as they will not be considered in the shortlisting for this position.

The closing date for applications is 12.00 midday on Monday 30 July 2018. Shop floor assessments and interviews will be held on Thursday 9 August 2018 you will need to be available on this day. Please note in normal circumstances only interview travel expenses within the UK will be reimbursed.
vacancy.orgGroupLocationText: Ashmolean Museum, Beaumont Street, Oxford

vacancy.shortDescription: Software and Hardware Engineer for Energy Systems
vacancy.jobDescription:
We are looking for an energetic, dedicated professional Software/Hardware Engineer to join a world-class multi-institution team, who will be predominantly responsible for supporting a fantastic and growing team that is making step changes in energy systems both in the developed and developing world and at local and global scales. The post will be funded from a range of EPSRC and Innovate UK projects and is fixed-term for 36 months.

You will be required to maintain and develop our code base and support its application in multiple domains and work closely with researchers to understand the strengths and weaknesses of the existing embedded hardware and code base.

The postholder will hold a degree in electrical engineering or a related subject (or equivalent) and experience of systems engineering involving the coupling or embedding of large software projects to hardware and the cloud. Demonstrable excellence in Python and CAD/CAM is also essential.

You should also have enthusiasm for working on new smart energy systems ranging from local to global and the ability to work to tight deadlines and relish the opportunity implicit in trials and demonstrations. The desire to learn new skills and a practical understanding of how to apply research products to solve real world problems is also required.

Informal enquiries may be addressed to: malcolm.mcculloch@eng.ox.ac.uk.

You will be required to upload a covering letter, clearly describing how your skillset matches the essential and desired criteria of this advertised position, CV and the details of two referees as part of your online application.

Only applications received before 12.00 midday on Wednesday 8 August 2018 can be considered.

The Department holds an Athena Swan Bronze award, highlighting its commitment to promoting women in Science, Engineering and Technology. This group has a strong desire to promote diversity and gender balance.

vacancy.jobDescription:
An opportunity has arisen within the Student Data Management and Analysis (SDMA) team for a Statistical Analyst. This post is offered at an exciting time with data increasingly being seen as an essential commodity assisting the Universitys decision and policy making and the post holder will be actively engaged with this programme of work.

The post involves the provision and analysis of applicant and student data for internal and external use, for operational needs as well as to support the formulation and implementation of admissions and academic policies. If you like transforming data into meaningful insight to aid decision-making at all levels of an organisation, we would like to hear from you.

The post holder will work with senior colleagues to identify areas of work and will be responsible for advising on the direction of the analysis undertaken, carrying out the analysis using a range of specialist techniques and software as well as presenting the relevant statistical evidence and findings clearly and concisely both verbally and in writing.

You will have exceptional statistical analysis and data management skills alongside experience of reporting, data analysis and data quality assurance. Successful candidates will produce high-quality written reports and contribute in a significant way to strategic development work and policy analysis.

You will have a strong educational background including a first degree (or equivalent), preferably in a subject containing a significant element of mathematics or statistics, and a higher qualification relating to data analysis would be advantageous

For an informal discussion about the position, please contact Katy Holmes, Head of SDMA, tel: (01865) 286377, email: katy.holmes@admin.ox.ac.uk.katy.holmes@admin.ox.ac.uk

Applications for this vacancy should be made online and you will be required to upload a CV and supporting statement as part of your application. The closing date for applications is 12:00 noon on Friday 17 August 2018. Interviews are expected to be held in the week commencing Monday 3 September 2018.

vacancy.jobDescription:
THIS IS A READVERTISEMENT. PREVIOUS APPLICANTS NEED NOT APPLY.

We are looking for an exceptional candidate with a track-record of effective project management and excellent interpersonal skills to join the Medical Sciences Divisional Office in a key role to deliver strategic research bids and the Research Excellence Framework (REF). In this new senior position, the postholder will deploy their expertise and knowledge to develop strategic and practical advice, articulate compelling narratives and scrutinise and interpret data.

As the Strategic Bids Manager, you will have developed excellent project management and interpersonal skills, facilitated effective collaborative working, influenced and supported academic and professional staff at all levels to deliver successful large-scale, complex projects. You will also demonstrate excellent analytical capability and verbal and written communication skills, providing strategic advice balanced alongside practical guidance and operational leadership. In handling a demanding and varied workload, you must be able to work independently as part of a wider team, enjoy the challenge of working in a complex organisation, managing your time and prioritising work effectively and efficiently to tight deadlines. You will manage at least one team member, which you will recruit.

This is an exceptional and almost unique opportunity to experience and shape a wide range and variety of strategic initiatives, giving invaluable insights into how these work at the university, and to demonstrate and showcase world-leading research excellence. For those interested in building a long-term and successful career in research support, experience of working on strategic bids and the REF at the UKs highest-ranked research-intensive university provides an opportunity to deliver major and critical projects.

If you are interested in applying, please contact the Assistant Registrar (Research), Leila Whitworth, by email at: leila.whitworth@medsci.ox.ac.uk to arrange an informal discussion about this post.

This is a permanent, full-time post. Part-time (minimum 0.8 FTE) would be considered.

You will be required to upload your CV and a supporting statement as part of your online application.

The closing date for applications is 12.00 midday on 9 August 2018. Interviews will be held on Tuesday 21 August 2018.

vacancy.jobDescription:
The Nuffield Department of Population Health (NDPH) contains world-renowned population health research groups and it provides an excellent environment for multi-disciplinary research and teaching. The department is home to major international research institutes such as the Clinical Trial Service Unit (CTSU) and is a key partner in the new Oxford University Big Data Institute (BDI).

As a Systems Analyst, you will be part of a team responsible for requirement gathering, analysis and documentation activities for CTSUs large-scale clinical trials and for major clinical research projects conducted in CTSU and the BDI. The focus of the role will be to determine and document requirements for new software and will require close liaison with academic staff, principal investigators, systems developers and the validation and testing group.

To be considered, you will be educated to degree level (or equivalent), have demonstrable experience of analysing and managing requirements for a range of IT projects and demonstrable problem solving ability. You will also have strong proficiency in a range of computer applications and excellent interpersonal and communication skills.

The position is full-time (part-time considered) and fixed-term for 2 years.

The closing date for applications is 12.00 noon on 20 August 2018.

vacancy.jobDescription:
The Nuffield Department of Population Health (NDPH) contains world-renowned population health research groups and provides an excellent environment for multi-disciplinary research and teaching. The department is home to major international research institutes such as the Clinical Trial Service Unit (CTSU) and is a key partner in the new Oxford University Big Data Institute (BDI).

As a Systems Tester, you will be part of a team responsible for the testing and validation procedures for major clinical research projects conducted in CTSU and the BDI. You will be involved in the hands-on testing of all products and your main duties will include assisting with the implementation and documentation of testing, writing test scripts and revising and updating test plans.

To be considered, you will be educated to degree level (or have equivalent experience) and have hands on experience of manual testing of Windows and web based applications, writing bug reports and test report documentation. You will also have an imaginative and analytical approach and good written and oral communication skills in Chinese (e.g. Mandarin).
