vacancy.jobDescription:
The Department of Chemistry is opening its new, purpose-built practical undergraduate teaching laboratory in October 2018 and is looking for a Technician to support the busy new environment.
Reporting to the Senior Technician, the postholder will be responsible for the effective maintenance and smooth running of the Teaching Laboratories.

You will be required to carry out a range of tasks from ensuring all equipment and items for experiments are available when required, maintenance and repair of equipment, good stock control of all chemicals, and to ensure that students fully understand the experiments and how to use equipment correctly and safely. You will play a major role in demonstrating chemistry experiments to undergraduates, as well as participating in the outreach programme bringing chemistry to children and young adults, ensuring compliance to health and safety at all times.

You will have a good training in chemistry or a related subject (minimum A-level ) or have equivalent experience. The successful candidates will have previous experience of working in a busy laboratory, and will have a strong understanding of Health and Safety, COSHH, and safe storage and use of chemicals. You will also need to be able to communicate effectively with a wide range of people from young children to academics providing pastoral care where required.

This post requires an enhanced DBS check.

You will be based in the Chemistry Teaching Laboratory on South Parks Road.

Applications for this vacancy are to be made online, you will be required to upload a CV and supporting statement as part of your online application.

The closing date for applications is 12.00 midday on Friday 24 August 2018.

vacancy.jobDescription:
To be successful in this role, you will need to hold an HNC or Bachelors degree or equivalent in a physical science or engineering-related subject, and have extensive experience of working in a laboratory. Your knowledge should include the safe use of chemicals, electronic equipment and mechanical equipment. You will need to be able to demonstrate experience in the construction, maintenance and operation of specialised equipment. You will be an excellent communicator, with a proven ability for accurate and timely record keeping. You will also be self-motivated, proactive and able to work unsupervised; as well as enjoy working and communicating with young people. If you have experience of teaching or training others (in particular experimental/practical science or technology) that would also be advantageous.

In this role you will be the senior technician in the Teaching Laboratory of the Department of Materials. You will have general responsibility for:
(i) supporting all teaching activities carried out in the Teaching Laboratory, including those for visiting school pupils, and for oversight of the use of the Teaching Laboratory facilities by researchers,
(ii) the equipment used in the Teaching Laboratory,
(iii) the organisation and operation of the Teaching Laboratory facility,
(iv) day-to-day responsibility for health & safety in the Teaching Laboratory (we would also train you to be one of the Departments first-aiders), and
(v) record keeping associated with the operation of the Teaching Laboratory;

This is a permanent post, funded by the Department of Materials, and is based primarily at the Department of Materials, Holder Building, Parks Road, Oxford.

All applications are to be made online, and you will be required to upload a supporting statement and CV as part of your application.

vacancy.shortDescription: Training Manager on Endangered Archaeology Project
vacancy.jobDescription:
Applications are invited for a Training Manager to join the Endangered Archaeology in the Middle East and North Africa (EAMENA) project in the School of Archaeology at the University of Oxford. The position is externally funded by the Cultural Protection Fund, administered by the British Council. The project director is Dr Robert Bewley and the principal investigator is Professor Andrew Wilson.

The postholder will be a member of a University of Oxford research group that is collaborating in the EAMENA project with archaeologists at the University of Leicester and University of Durham. The main responsibilities of the post involve the design, organisation and delivery of training for employees of the antiquities services of Jordan and the State of Palestine as well as contributing to the creation of key datasets within the EAMENA framework specific to the national archaeological services of Jordan and Palestine. This will involve compilation of data from published surveys and site gazetteers, creation of lists of key sites of each country and a watch list of 250-300 sites representative of the region's heritage.

The postholder will act as a key liaison between the national archaeological services of Jordan and Palestine and the EAMENA project, working with team members and training staff to promote and facilitate the potential adoption of a country-based heritage platform (HER) based on the EAMENA database. In addition the postholder will contribute to the general work of the EAMENA project: interpretation of satellite imagery and aerial photographs, creation of new site records, data management (using standard terminology and data input), analysis and archaeological research in support of the aims of the Endangered Archaeology project covering Jordan and Palestine. The postholder will provide guidance to junior members of the research group including research assistants, PhD students, and/or project volunteers.

The post is a full-time appointment, for a fixed-term until 31 December 2019 and is available from July 2018.

Applicants must have a doctorate in Archaeology (or a related and relevant subject) together with experience in or knowledge of the Middle East and North Africa. You will have experience of organising and delivering training events, teaching, workshops or conferences and be a good communicator and organiser. Applicants should also possess specialist knowledge in archaeological survey techniques, especially image interpretation and site record creation.

Further details are avilable from Dr. Robert Bewley using the email address below.

Additional information about the project is available at: http://eamena.arch.ox.ac.uk

The closing date for applications is 12.00 noon on Friday 27 July 2018.

vacancy.jobDescription:
The Nuffield Department of Population Health (NDPH) contains world-renowned population health research groups and provides an excellent environment for multi-disciplinary research and teaching. NDPH is home to the Clinical Trial Service Unit (CTSU), a major international research institute and is also a key partner is the new Oxford University Big Data Institute.

As Data Analyst you will join a team that is responsible for the processing and integration of large and diverse amounts of data collected by CTSU to be used for research purposes. You will be responsible for checking the quality and consistency of the data, creating appropriate documentation, making the data available to internal and external parties in a suitable format and answering queries in a timely manner.

To be considered for the Data Analyst role, you will need to have an MSc (or equivalent) in a scientific or numerate subject and proficiency in database management and in using large relational databases. You will also be proficient in one or more statistical software package (e.g. SAS, R or Stata).

Informal enquiries should be addressed to Dr Naomi Allen (naomi.allen@ndph.ox.ac.uk).

vacancy.jobDescription:
The Tax Team is part of the Finance Division that supports departmental accounting functions to ensure accurate tax compliance and reporting, and to effectively manage tax risk. It also provides an information and advisory service to the University community that will include new building constructions, research activities, major projects, investments, overseas issues and trading subsidiaries. Oxford University Press operates with a high degree of autonomy but is part of the whole legal entity that is the University and which shares common tax reporting.

The University operates under a Partial Exemption Special Method agreed with HMRC to fairly attribute input VAT with outputs and to determine the level of recoverability. This reflects the variety of different supplies that the University makes, and which includes large amounts of exempt education and non-business grant funded research. Costs relating to non-recoverable input VAT are partly mitigated by the reliefs available for medical research and supplies that are closely related to education.

Having recently implemented a tax engine within Oracle Financials Release 12 we are looking to further strengthen our VAT accounting processes to provide a consistent approach to determining the correct accounting treatment across a wide range of transactions.

The Tax Team comprises four staff working in close cooperation under the general direction of the Tax Manager. On a day-to-day basis, the VAT Assistant works under the direction of the VAT Manager.

You will be primarily responsible for creating and maintaining the master data fields for new suppliers and customers within the Oracle R12 accounting system. This information drives the tax engine. You will also be required to analyse the validity of transaction data entered into the tax engine. The work will fit within an ongoing schedule of data analysis and investigation including a monthly reconciliation of analysing exceptions. Other duties will include working with other teams, such as Purchasing, IT and Payments to improve processes and responding to departmental user queries.

To make an application online please follow the link www.michaelpage.co.uk/job-detail/vat-assistant/ref/13933157?source=search or contact Michael Page directly via 0186 520 8782, job ref: 13933157

The closing date for applications is 12.00 noon on Friday 27 July 2018.

vacancy.jobDescription:
THIS POST MAY ALSO BE OFFERED AS A SECONDMENT OPPORTUNITY.

The Estates Services Facilities Management (FM) team are currently responsible for generating income from four venues  Examination Schools, Sheldonian Theatre, St Lukes Chapel and Osler House. They market their services to customers inside and outside the University under the umbrella brand Oxford University Event Venues. More details here: www.venues.ox.ac.uk.

The Venues team are looking to recruit for a full-time fixed-term maternity cover. You will need to be a proactive, customer orientated individual with a can do attitude. Highly organised with great attention to detail, you will thrive in working as part of a team in a busy environment where multi-tasking is essential. With a sales background, you will have strong telephone and written communication skills and be able to demonstrate a track record in driving revenue, managing events and building positive relationships with customers.

This is a full-time fixed-term appointment (maternity cover) for 1 year.

Some out of hours working and weekend working will be required on occasions.

The closing date for applications is 12.00 noon on Thursday 2 August 2018.
vacancy.orgGroupLocationText: Estates Services, Oxford.

vacancy.jobDescription:
We are recruiting an additional Visitor Services Assistant working under the supervision of the Front of House Manager to join our busy team. The postholder will provide a friendly welcome to all visitors and assistance with enquiries. They will also encourage donations to the Museum and conversions to Gift Aid. The Visitor Services Assistant will play an important role in ensuring visitor safety and in the security of the building.

The post requires excellent interpersonal skills, a professional attitude and a flexible approach to work. Ideally the postholder will have experience of working in a museum or heritage visitor attraction, or a similar customer-focussed environment.

The successful candidate will have a confident and pro-active approach to dealing with problems and issues as well as a positive attitude and a desire to gain knowledge of the Museum and to share this with our visitors.

Applicants are required to complete the online application form and include a supporting statement addressing the selection criteria.

For further details on the Museum please see our website: www.oum.ox.ac.uk. Please contact Front of House Manager Krista Baker using the contact details below.

The closing date for applications is 12.00 noon on Monday 6 August 2018. Interviews will be held on Wednesday 15 August 2018.
vacancy.orgGroupLocationText: Museum of Natural History, Oxford

vacancy.jobDescription:
The Gerald Averay Wainwright Fellow is a postdoctoral research fellowship role. The intention is to offer an opportunity for an outstanding scholar at an early stage in her/his academic career to enhance that career through developing research experience and a publication record. The research may be conducted at any UK University with appropriate supervision in the designated areas.

The Fellow will carry out research into the non-classical archaeology (not literary or philological studies) of any country or countries of Northern Africa and the Near East (from Morocco to Afghanistan). This will involve managing the academic research and associated administration, through small-scale project management to co-ordinate multiple aspects of work within deadlines. The Fellow will adapt existing and develop new research methodologies and materials as necessary, preparing, reviewing and refining working theories and analysing data from a variety of sources. The preparation of research publication(s) is an important aspect of the role, as is present the research findings at appropriate forums. The Fellow will also develop a new research proposal or job application, and ideas for generating research income.

The successful applicant will present a credible proposal for research and publication in the relevant field, and ideally will have or plan to develop research impact and public engagement skills. Candidates must demonstrate advanced specialist knowledge in their discipline, and be able to to develop an effective and coherent research programme. Time management skills, the ability to set priorities and meet deadlines, and skills in analysis of data and research into complex ideas, concepts or theories, will be required.

This is a fixed-term position for 6 months.

The closing date for applications is 12.00 noon on 1 October 2018.

Note: the University is also currently advertising for another Wainwright Postdoctoral Fellow with a longer fixed-term, vacancy ref. 135292.

vacancy.jobDescription:
The Gerald Averay Wainwright Fellow is a prestigious postdoctoral research fellowship role. The intention is to offer an opportunity for an outstanding scholar at an early stage in her/his academic career to obtain experience in research. Ideally, applicants will demonstrate a strong prior association with the UK academic community. The research may be conducted at any UK University with appropriate supervision in the designated areas.

The Fellow will carry out a significant piece of publishable research into the non-classical archaeology (not literary or philological studies) of any country or countries of Northern Africa and the Near East (from Morocco to Afghanistan). This will involve managing the academic research and associated administration, through small-scale project management to co-ordinate multiple aspects of work within deadlines. The Fellow will adapt existing and develop new research methodologies and materials as necessary, preparing, reviewing and refining working theories and analysing data from a variety of sources. The preparation of research publication(s) is an important aspect of the role, as is present the research findings at appropriate forums. The Fellow will also develop new research proposals, and ideas for generating research income, as and when the opportunity arises.

The successful applicant will present a credible proposal for research and publication in the relevant field, and have or plan to develop research impact and public engagement skills. Demonstrating excellent skills in preparing research findings for publication, she/he will have the potential to produce outputs that will be recognised as excellent within the Research Excellence Framework. Candidates must demonstrate sufficient specialist knowledge in the discipline to develop an effective research programme, which is also coherent, well-organised and deliverable. Time management skills, the ability to set priorities and meet deadlines, and skills in analysis of and research into complex ideas, concepts or theories, will be required.

This is a fixed-term position, for 1 year initially with the potential to be renewed for up to a further 2 years.

The closing date for applications is 12.00 noon on 1 October 2018.

Note: the University is currently also advertising for a Wainwright Early Career Fellowship for 6 months, vacancy ref 135291

vacancy.shortDescription: Widening Access and Participation Assistant (maternity cover)
vacancy.jobDescription:
Applications are invited for the post of assistant within the Widening Access and Participation team to contribute towards the Universitys Flagship Outreach programme, UNIQ.

The postholder with have a key role in the organisation and delivery of the programme which aims at raising the aspirations of students studying at UK state schools and colleges regarding their higher education choices.

The post advertised involves the provision of logistical, administrative and practical support to the Widening Access and Participation Coordinators and Manager. This is an important role within the team, and will contribute towards ensuring the adequate planning, thorough development and professional delivery of the key strategic areas of the UNIQ programme.

We are therefore seeking a hardworking and conscientious individual who can provide support for the programme at all levels. This would be an excellent opportunity for applicants wishing to further develop their skills and knowledge in Higher Education outreach work.

Owing to the nature of this position, any offer of employment with the University will be subject to a satisfactory disclosure report from the Disclosure and Barring Service.

The closing date for applications is 12.00 noon on Monday 30 July 2018, only applications received before then will be considered. Interviews are anticipated to take place week commencing 13 August 2018.
